urn:contentItem:63HD-R711-JDKC-R065-00000-00WMO: WEATHER DISASTERS UP FIVEFOLD IN 1970-20192021-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:13:51ZLexisNexisWMO: WEATHER DISASTERS UP FIVEFOLD IN 1970-2019

TOKYO, Sept. 2 -- NHK World issued the following news:

The UN weather agency says weather disasters increased fivefold in the past half-century, killing more than 2 million people and causing losses of over 3 trillion dollars.

The World Meteorological Organization on Wednesday released a report on the more than 11,000 weather disasters, such as floods and heat waves, that struck between 1970 and 2019, as well as the economic losses incurred. It notes over 90 percent of the deaths occurred in developing countries.

In Asia, more than 975,000 lives were lost through storms and floods, accounting for nearly half the casualties. One particularly deadly disaster was a cyclone that hit Myanmar in 2008, claiming over 130,000 lives.

Africa accounts for 35 percent of weather-associated deaths reported globally. Droughts led to the highest number of fatalities, accounting for 95 percent of all lives lost in the continent.

The report says economic losses, standing at 3.64 trillion dollars during the 50-year period, have jumped sevenfold.

Notable examples are Hurricane Katrina, which made landfall in the southern United States in 2005, causing damages of nearly 164 billion dollars, and the 2017 Hurricane Harvey, which led to losses of almost 96 billion dollars.

The report says improved multi-hazard early warning systems have significantly reduced mortality, but much more remains to be done, as only half of the 193 members of the WMO have such systems.

Meeting reporters, WMO Secretary-General Petteri Taalas said investment is needed both in the observation systems and early warning services of the countries.

He stressed the need to assist developing countries, saying forecasting high-impact weather events such as flooding or storms can save lives and also prevent economic losses. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at contentservices@htlive.com

urn:contentItem:6733-R8G1-DYMD-63P9-00000-00UPDATE1: U.S. seeks stronger ties with Africa in 3-day summit amid China clout2022-12-14T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:13:50ZLexisNexisUPDATE1: U.S. seeks stronger ties with Africa in 3-day summit amid China cloutWASHINGTON, Dec. 13

A three-day U.S.-Africa summit began on Tuesday in Washington, with President Joe Biden's administration planning to commit $55 billion over the next three years to support the continent, where China is increasing its economic clout.

A total of 49 countries and the African Union have been invited to the event for talks on cooperation on a range of issues such as trade and investment, security, health and climate, and space.

On Tuesday, the Biden administration announced the expansion of Washington's space partnerships by welcoming the first African signatories -- Nigeria and Rwanda -- to the Artemis Accords laying out principles toward peaceful exploration and use of outer space, bringing the total participants to 23 nations.

The accords also support activities of the Artemis project, a U.S.-led international effort aimed at advancing lunar exploration and eventually sending astronauts on missions to Mars. Other nations that have joined the accords include Japan, South Korea, Australia and France.

A senior State Department official stressed the need for space cooperation, citing how a Nigerian satellite became the first to deliver urgently needed first images showing the scale of damage when Hurricane Katrina hit southeastern United States in 2005.

Upon announcing its hosting of the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit, the White House said the gathering will "demonstrate the United States' enduring commitment to Africa, and will underscore the importance of U.S.-Africa relations and increased cooperation on shared global priorities."

Biden also intends to announce during the event U.S. support for the AU to join the Group of 20 major economies as a permanent member, hoping to bring more voices from Africa into the international forum, according to White House National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan.

While Sullivan has said the summit is "about the affirmative agenda that the United States has to bring to bear with Africa" and not about attempting to compare with "other countries," the U.S.-China rivalry over the continent seems to be increasing.

U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin warned during one session on peace and security that activities by China and Russia in Africa bear "watching" and their influence "can be destabilizing."

He said China is expanding its footprint on the continent "on a daily basis" and also expanding its economic influence, adding that "they're not always transparent in terms of what they're doing and that creates problems that will be eventually destabilizing, if they're not already."

Russia, meanwhile, continues "to peddle cheap weapons" and employ mercenaries across the continent.

Some experts say that while the summit is welcome, such a gathering is "overdue" in light of China's increasing involvement in Africa, including through its Belt and Road infrastructure projects.

"Over the decades since the Cold War, Chinese influence in Africa has increased significantly, while U.S. influence has flatlined," Thomas Sheehy, who examines the role of Beijing in Africa at the U.S. Institute of Peace, wrote in a commentary posted on the organization's website earlier this month.

China has been holding the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation every three years since 2000, while other nations including Russia and Japan also hold Africa summits. The latest U.S.-Africa gathering, however, is only the second Africa summit held by the United States, with the first occurring in 2014, according to Sheehy.

China's first overseas military base has been established in the East African nation of Djibouti on the Bab el Mandeb Strait, a chokepoint between the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden.

==Kyodo

urn:contentItem:6735-90D1-JC5B-G0FW-00000-00UPDATE2: U.S. seeks stronger ties with Africa in summit amid China inroads2022-12-14T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:13:51ZLexisNexisUPDATE2: U.S. seeks stronger ties with Africa in summit amid China inroadsWASHINGTON, Dec. 14

A three-day U.S.-Africa summit began on Tuesday in Washington, with President Joe Biden's administration planning to commit $55 billion over the next three years to support the continent, where China has been increasing its economic clout.

A total of 49 countries and the African Union have been invited to the event for talks on cooperation on a range of issues such as trade and investment, security, health and climate, and space.

On Tuesday, the Biden administration announced the expansion of Washington's space partnerships by welcoming the first African signatories -- Nigeria and Rwanda -- to the Artemis Accords laying out principles toward peaceful exploration and use of outer space, bringing the total participants to 23 nations.

The accords also support activities of the Artemis project, a U.S.-led international effort aimed at advancing lunar exploration and eventually sending astronauts on missions to Mars. Other nations that have joined the accords include Japan, South Korea, Australia and France.

A senior State Department official stressed the need for space cooperation, citing how a Nigerian satellite became the first to deliver urgently needed first images showing the scale of damage when Hurricane Katrina hit the southeastern United States in 2005.

Upon announcing its hosting of the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit, the White House said the gathering will "demonstrate the United States' enduring commitment to Africa and will underscore the importance of U.S.-Africa relations and increased cooperation on shared global priorities."

Biden also intends to announce during the event U.S. support for the AU to join the Group of 20 major economies as a permanent member, hoping to bring more voices from Africa into the international forum, according to White House National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan.

While Sullivan has said the summit is "about the affirmative agenda that the United States has to bring to bear with Africa" and not about attempting to compare with "other countries," the U.S.-China rivalry over the continent seems to be increasing.

Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin warned during one session on peace and security that activities by China and Russia in Africa bear "watching" and their influence "can be destabilizing."

Russia, meanwhile, continues "to peddle cheap weapons" and employ mercenaries across the continent.

The Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin claimed at a press conference in Beijing Wednesday that China is a "good friend, partner and brother" of Africa and the country is "sincerely welcomed by the African people."

He expressed hope that the United States will view China-Africa cooperation "with an open mind" and called on Washington to "respect the wishes of the African people and take concrete actions to help Africa develop instead of making a big fuss about smearing and attacking other countries."

Some experts say that while the summit is welcome, such a gathering is "overdue" in light of China's increasing involvement in Africa, including through its Belt and Road infrastructure projects.

China has been holding the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation every three years since 2000, while other nations including Russia and Japan also hold Africa summits. The latest U.S.-Africa gathering, however, is only the second Africa summit held by the United States, with the first occurring in 2014, according to Sheehy.

China's first overseas military base has been established in the East African nation of Djibouti on the Bab el Mandeb Strait, a chokepoint between the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden.

urn:contentItem:60F1-YT41-JCH9-G1JW-00000-00How Will the Covid-19 Pandemic Change the New International Order?2020-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:13:51ZLexisNexisHow Will the Covid-19 Pandemic Change the New International Order?

With 7 million confirmed cases worldwide and 400,000 lives lost, it has been up to each nation to cope with the common challenge of Covid-19.

The Schengen Agreement, a pillar of the European Union's integration plan, has de facto been suspended in order for the member countries' government to regain border controls.

The movement of people globally has been banned by many nations, and by the same token even movement across provinces within countries has been regarded with hostility under self-isolation policies. Logically a pandemic will not spread if we can prevent those infected from coming into contact with other susceptible people. But with Covid-19, we have been forced to isolate people without knowing who is infected. It was an operation to buy time in the hope that treatment drugs or vaccines would soon arrive, while the general lockdown of cities would ease the pressure on existing medical infrastructure. Some countries have generally succeeded in containing the spread of the virus, including Japan with a death toll of under 1,000 and few new cases. But the game is not over.

The SARSCov-2 virus which caused Covid-19 has a complicated structure and is already mutating. We will have to live with this virus for a considerably long time, and what is needed now is not simply a better way to fight this medical emergency, but a way to create a new order of society, economy and national security.

The coming long battle against the Corona virus will require us to mobilize all our resources. We will need a healthy economy, industries and enterprises to provide finance, technology and human resources. More importantly, on the domestic front, trust among communities and societies has to be reestablished. But are the social changes we can observe caused by the Corona virus? Or has it merely accelerated changes already taking place? The problem of income and asset discrepancies, for example, has been further emphasized due to the disproportionate suffering of some people from the pandemic, and it has also highlighted tardiness in society's response to digital transformation and the digital divide in society. On the international front, free movement of goods and services, money and people have supported globalization. In particular, foreign direct investment (FDI), technology-transfer and movement of engineers are essential for the workings of supply-value chains. But are these global chains going to be destroyed by the Corona virus? Let us reflect on several incidents of the past decades. During the Oil Crisis of the 1970s, energy producing countries such as the United States had the option of self-sufficiency while many other consumer countries needed energy trade, but even the US would have suffered extremely high oil prices once the global market price had skyrocketed. Henry Kissinger came up with the idea of creating the International Energy Agency (IEA) to create a strategic reserve system, to promote alternative energy sources such as coal and natural gas, and also to geographically diversify oil supply sources. He thought that national security and energy security were two sides of the same coin, and therefore selfreliance should not be a solution. This proved to be a boon following Hurricane Katrina in 2005, when US domestic supplies of refinery products saw a shortage, and the IEA mechanism and imports help to calm the market. Following the 2002-2004 SARS outbreak and then the antiJapanese demonstrations in China in 2012, Japanese enterprises launched a 'China+1' strategy to diversify their supply chains. Similarly, after the Great East Japan Earthquake in 2011 a European automaker that had been sourcing key equipment solely from a Japanese component maker decided to go back to traditional dual sourcing, as the sole supplier could not establish factories outside of Japan and guarantee replacement supplies without delay.

The lesson from these experiences is 'Don't put all your eggs in one basket.' By diversification, a more resilient supply system can be built and strengthened through international cooperation. Movements towards self-reliance will not realize resilience against external and internal risks. Some emerging economies are more vulnerable to such movements because they are more dependent on trade and FDI, and often have less efficient healthcare systems, in addition to weak governance in general. It is time for OECD countries to start extending help to developing countries in their efforts to cope with this pandemic. We hope this Corona virus challenge will not lead to divided communities, either domestically or internationally, but will accelerate the structural changes of each community. We should be optimistic that people will regain a sense of trust and belonging, and believe they are being listened to. We may then emerge as a stronger and more inclusive society.

urn:contentItem:4H1C-4BP0-00JR-G4V4-00000-00<published>2005-09-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:13:50Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IEA to release 2 mil. bpd in aftermath of Hurricane Katrina</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>PARIS, Sept. 2</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The International Energy Agency said Friday it has decided to release 2 million barrels of oil per day from strategic reserves in the wake of Hurricane Katrina which ripped through southern U.S. states, the International Energy Agency said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> 'All 26 IEA member countries will take collective action in response to the interrupted oil supplies in the Gulf of Mexico caused by Hurricane Katrina,' IEA Executive Director Claude Mandil said.</p><p>'The loss of production in the Gulf of Mexico and considerable damage to oil refining and transportation infrastructure constitute a serious disruption of supplies.'</p><p> The IEA said its member countries and the European Commission, the executive body of the European Union, unanimously back the measure to make available to the market the equivalent of 2 million barrels per day of oil for an initial period of 30 days.</p><p> 'Although the initial impact of the storm was regional, the implications for the oil market are global,' the IEA said. 'IEA member countries are acting in solidarity with the United States in addressing this loss and restoring confidence to the oil market. IEA member countries are aware that products and, in particular, gasoline, will be the most useful contribution.'</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4H16-MJW0-002V-11HB-00000-00<published>2005-09-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Hurricane Katrina Affects Some Japan Firms</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>Tokyo, Sept. 2</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Hurricane Katrina has disrupted resources development projects and some other U.S. operations involving Japanese companies, officials said Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Sumitomo Corp. <8053> does not know when it will be able to restart its natural gas production off Louisiana, because there has been no progress in its safety investigations, a company spokesman said.</p><p>The trading house halted the operations in late August, before the hurricane hit the southern part of the United States.</p><p>Nippon Oil Corp. <5001> officials said operations have been halted at 18 of the 27 natural gas and oil fields in which the company holds stakes in the Gulf of Mexico.</p><p>Of the 18 fields damaged by the hurricane, nine will be able to resume operations in one or two weeks, but no such plan has been set for the remaining nine because investigations are still going on, the officials said.</p><p>Nippon Oil's stakes in the 27 fields give the company a daily oil output of well over 10,000 barrels.</p><p>JTB Corp., a major travel agency, was planning package tours in southern U.S. locations including New Orleans that were hit particularly hard by the hurricane. It has decided to cancel the tours scheduled to begin in late October.</p><p>New Orleans has the largest U.S. port for crop exports. Itochu Corp. <8001> and the National Federation of Agricultural Cooperative Association, known as Zenno, has a joint venture that transports produce from inland areas to the port. The U.S. joint venture is believed to have halted its operations. <br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>EU expresses support for victims of Hurricane Katrina</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEWPORT, Wales, Sept. 2</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">British Foreign Minister Jack Straw expressed deep concern and support Friday for the victims of Hurricane Katrina, which has devastated the southeastern United States.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> 'We would like to send our thoughts to the families and friends of those in Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama who lost their lives,' Straw said on behalf of the European Union Presidency at the informal summit of EU foreign ministers in the south Wales town of Newport.</p><p>'The EU has offered to help the United States with any assistance that might be required in what is perhaps the greatest civil emergency in U.S. history,' Straw said.</p><p> As well, Straw conveyed his and his counterparts' sympathy for the hundreds of people caught up in the Baghdad stampede Wednesday and added that their thoughts were also with the families and friends of those killed in the Beslan massacre on the anniversary of the tragedy.</p><p> The informal gathering of the EU foreign ministers is being held as part of a series of meetings forming Britain's presidency of the European Union.</p><p> The subject of Turkey's accession to the European Union has dominated the two-day summit and with Turkish Foreign Minister Abdullah Gul arriving in Britain to join the foreign ministers from the existing 25 EU member states, discussion is likely to heat up.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4H0R-6TV0-00JR-G495-00000-00<published>2005-08-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>68 killed as Hurricane Katrina rips through U.S. Gulf Coast</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Aug. 30</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The death toll from Hurricane Katrina that ripped through the U.S. Gulf Coast on Monday has reached 68 and local authorities said Tuesday the toll will rise further, CNN and other reports said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Mississippi Gov. Haley Barbour said, 'There are credible accounts of 50 to 80 in Harrison County.</p><p>Those are not confirmed, but they're credible.'</p><p> Many of New Orleans' 480,000 residents were evacuated over the weekend due to the approaching hurricane. About 9,000 people hunkered down in the Louisiana Superdome, around which water was knee-deep, the Associated Press said.</p><p> The killer hurricane also destroyed many houses and caused widespread flooding in New Orleans and other places in Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama after making landfall in southeastern Louisiana early Monday with winds of more than 224 kilometers per hour.</p><p> The National Hurricane Center said Katrina, one of the most powerful storms in U.S. history, became a tropical depression Tuesday but was still producing heavy rains.</p><p> As of 10 a.m. local time, the depression was about 40 kilometers south of Clarksville, Tennessee, moving north-northeast at about 34 kph. It is packing winds of about 56 kph with higher gusts and expected to become an extratropical during the next 12 to 24 hours, the center said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4H0H-7RN0-00JR-G44B-00000-00<published>2005-08-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:32Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Hurricane Katrina weakens after pounding Gulf Coast</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Aug. 29</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Hurricane Katrina gradually weakened Monday afternoon after pounding the Gulf Coast with winds of more than 224 kilometers per hour and making landfall in southeastern Louisiana, the National Weather Service reported.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> According to CNN, Mississippi Gov. Haley Barbour told reporters that Katrina 'came in on Mississippi like a ton of bricks.' He also expressed fear 'that there are a lot of dead people down there.'</p><p>About a million people fled the New Orleans area and an estimated 10,000 people hunkered down in the Louisiana Superdome, which is home to the New Orleans Saints, CNN reported.</p><p> President George W. Bush, during a speech in Arizona, warned residents of the affected region to take precautions, and said that the federal government would assist in the aftermath of the storm.</p><p> 'This is a dangerous storm,' he said. 'When the storm passes, the federal government has got assets and resources that we'll be deploying to help you.'</p><p> The weather service said the hurricane, one of the most powerful storms in U.S. history, struck southeastern Louisiana and southern Mississippi before weakening over land.</p><p> At 2 p.m. Monday local time, the weather service said, the center of the hurricane was located about 32 kilometers west-southwest of Hattiesburg, Mississippi, and moving toward the north at about 29 kph.</p><p> Saying Katrina is 'still dangerous,' the weather service warned, 'Hurricane force winds are expected to spread as far as 150 miles (240 km) inland along the path of Katrina.'</p><p> The weather service's radar estimate show that rainfall totals of more than 130 to nearly 200 centimeters have occurred over portions of extreme southern Mississippi.</p><p> Katrina is expected to weaken to a tropical storm Tuesday as remnant rain moves northward toward the Ohio Valley, the weather service said.</p><p> On Sunday, New Orleans Mayor Ray Nagin ordered residents to evacuate, saying, 'This is a once-in-a-lifetime event.'</p><p>CNN said three residents of a New Orleans nursing home died Sunday while being evacuated to Baton Rouge. But it was not clear if the deaths were storm-related.</p><p> At least seven people were killed in Florida, where Katrina made landfall Thursday, the report said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Pets lost in Hurricane Katrina receive food and shelter</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW ORLEANS, Louisiana, Sept. 13</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">In addition to the thousands of people made homeless by Hurricane Katrina, many pets are being sheltered in temporary homes around the country.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> At the Parker Coliseum of Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge, 1,287 pets, including 787 dogs and 451 cats as well as pigs, rabbits and ferrets, are waiting to go home again with their owners.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The shelter opened Sept. 1, four days after the hurricane hit the area, and about 200 animals have been picked up by their owners so far.</p><p>'We know all the owners of animals here and we take good care of them until owners are able to bring them back home again,' said Virginia Guttner, a public affairs official at the shelter.</p><p> There are four to five veterinarians stationed at the shelter 24 hours a day and all the animals are examined and photographed when they first arrive to determine whether they need any further medical treatment.</p><p> 'We keep track of the schedule of all the animals when they are fed and walked,' Guttner explains.</p><p> Most of the necessary supplies are covered by donations. 'We totally appreciate the generosity of the people who donated and now we have dog food for years,' said Guttner. 'Now we appreciate money more than supplies.'</p><p> The shelter is looking for temporary foster parents for animals because they do not know how long they will maintain the facility.</p><p>New Orleans international airport has since Wednesday allowed owners to take their pets with them.</p><p> 'I've waited till the day I can evacuate with my dog,' said Sterling Kenneth, a 47-year-old construction worker from the eastern part of New Orleans who was on his way to Atlanta where his relatives live, with his brother and neighbor.</p><p> 'I saw horrible scenes like robbery in my neighborhood but I would not go anywhere without my two dogs,' said Amanda Garhardt from downtown New Orleans en route to Baton Rouge.</p><p>Texas oil tycoon Boone Pickens airlifted about 80 pets from Louisiana to their new homes in California by chartered airplane on Sunday.</p><p> However, those animals that evacuated with their owners or in shelters are the lucky ones. Hundreds of people were forced to leave their pets behind during the storm evacuation, creating emotional scenes of abandoned and starving animals having to fend for themselves.</p><p> Andrew Rowan, executive vice president of operations for the Humane SocietyUnited States, told the Associated Press that perhaps 50,000 or more dogs and cats in New Orleans still need to be rescued.</p><p> 'As long as there are animals that need to be taken care of, we'll be here to help them and that's what keeps us going,' said Guttner.</p><p> The website petfinder.com has set up a database of pet pictures to help owners find their lost pets.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4H2T-F890-01G8-F0V7-00000-00<published>2005-09-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>OMRON Corporation and OMRON Management Center of America Pledge 300,000 US Dollars for Victims of Hurricane Katrina</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>Tokyo, Japan</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Sept 8, 2005 OMRON Corporation and OMRON Management Center of America have pledged a total of 300,000 US dollars to support victims and aid reconstruction in the areas recently devastated by Hurricane Katrina. OMRON Corporation's contribution will be made through the JapanRed Cross, while OMRON Management Center of America will make a donation to the USRed Cross through OMRON Foundation Inc. The donation from Omron Foundation, Inc. includes a matching gift from equaling the total value of contributions made by U.S. employees.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"I am sure I speak for Omron Group employees worldwide when I say that our hearts go out to all those who have been affected by this disaster. We pray for those people who lost their lives in this tragedy and the families they left behind, and hope that these donations will help the recovery process in some small way," said OMRON Corporation President & CEO, Hisao Sakuta.</p><p>About OMRON Foundation, Inc.</p><p>Founded in 1989, the OMRON Foundation [OFI] coordinates the charitable efforts of all OMRON offices in the US and Canada to achieve the greatest positive social impact. The Foundation is funded by OMRON's subsidiaries in North America, who contribute 0.1% of their sales, as well as money from OMRON Management Center of America.</p><p>The Foundation divides its charitable resources among organizations benefiting education, people with disabilities, cultural pursuits, the aged, and other social concerns such as disaster relief.</p><p>About OMRON</p><p>Headquartered in Kyoto, Japan, OMRON Corporation is a global leader in the field of automation. Established in 1933 and headed by President Hisao Sakuta, Omron has more than 25,000 employees in over 35 countries working to provide products and services to customers in a variety of fields including industrial automation, electronic components industries, and healthcare. The company is divided into five regions and head offices are in Japan [Kyoto], Asia Pacific [Singapore], China [Hong Kong], Europe [Amsterdam] and US [Chicago]. The European organisation has its own development and manufacturing facilities, and provides local customer support in all European countries. For more information, visit Omron's Web site at <url normalizedValue="http://www.omron.com">www.omron.com</url>. </p><p>Contact:<br/><br/>Takayuki Nakamura <br/><email normalizedValue="mailto:takayuki_nakamura@omron.co.jp">takayuki_nakamura@omron.co.jp</email><br/>James Seddon <br/><email normalizedValue="mailto:james_seddon@omron.co.jp">james_seddon@omron.co.jp</email><br/>OMRON Corporate Brand Communications Department<br/><br/></p><p>K.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">JCN-JCN10817</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JCN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4H2T-F890-01G8-F0V7-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">256331</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-25</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="392"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>JCN Newswire</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2005 JCN Newswire. urn:contentItem:4H70-9FS0-001X-J0BK-00000-00<published>2005-09-29T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Pg. 14</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Japan rallies for victims of Hurricane Katrina</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Les Coles / Daily Yomiuri Staff Writer</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Musicians in Japan are banding together to raise money for the victims of Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true">One reason for the massive outpouring of support is that the two hardest-hit areas--Louisiana and Mississippi--are the home of jazz and the blues, respectively, and many musicians feel a link that is almost spiritual to the two areas.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Japan's music industry received an enormous number of gifts from the southern part of the United States--namely blues and jazz," said Reiko Yukawa, the organizer of Hurricane Aid Japan, a group of 20 or so musicians that is raising funds for Katrina victims through concerts and other events.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Dubbed the "Godmother" of the Japanese music industry, Yukawa has been a music journalist and writer for 45 years, and has many friends in New Orleans. "We were raised listening to jazz, blues and rock 'n' roll music," Yukawa said in an e-mail interview with The Daily Yomiuri. "Watching CNN and the news from Louisiana, I thought we [those in the music industry] should do something about it, because we owe a lot to people in New Orleans."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Yomiuri</p></bodyText></section><p>As synchronicity had it, New Orleans' most recognizable voice--Dr. John--had been booked to play Tokyo, so Yukawa contacted him to explain her proposal, asking him to attend a press conference at Blue Note in Tokyo on Sept. 21, held to formally launch Hurricane Aid Japan. Adding his own gravelly voice to the appeal, Dr. John said: "There are a lot of forgotten people. People who got no money, no food, no medical treatment."</p><p>Japanese jazzers at the press conference included clarinetist Eiji Kitamura; pianist Saya, who has played with Dr. John and with the Neville Brothers and who is contributing all the proceeds from her current tour to New Orleans; trumpeter Terumasa Hino, and gospel singer Yuka Kaebuchi, as well as pop veteran Akiko Wada.</p><p>Hino, who was doing a tour of Japan with other artists including Toku and Fried Pride, raised 2.5 million yen at nine gigs in September. Admittedly, Hino used a hard-sell technique.</p><p>Rather than doing the usual thing of leaving a box on stage and asking people to put their donations in it, Hino suggested band members stand at the doors and collect donations from people as they left the venues, according to a spokesperson for Hino.</p><p>Having raised all this money, Hino didn't know what to do with it, so he contacted Yukawa and thus become involved with Hurricane Aid Japan, the spokesperson said. Despite the success of Hino's slightly unorthodox method of fund-raising, he apparently wants to help organize a more formal benefit concert before the year is out.</p><p>U.S. musicians resident in Japan naturally also are doing their bit. Earlier in the month, on Sept. 13, Democrats Abroad Japan held a benefit at the Pink Cow in Shibuya, Tokyo. "It was a moderate success, especially given the short time line to pull everything together," said Matt Kass, who helped organize the event. "In the end, we had excellent performances, about 40 attendees and raised 200,000 yen--100 percent of which will go to charities such as Red Cross [and] Oxfam."</p><p>The organization is following the event up with a benefit on Oct. 25 at B-Flat in Akasaka, Tokyo. Originally, the event was to be held on Sept. 24, but was rescheduled for a variety of reasons. "Too many unpredictable factors such as securing talent, reserving a quality venue and adequate promotions for another successful benefit event in a short time frame," Kass said.</p><p>Earlier next month, The Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan (FCCJ) is hosting a special event on Oct. 8., from 4:30 p.m. to 10:30 p.m., at the FCCJ Press Club in Yurakucho, Tokyo.</p><p>The fund-raiser will include authentic Cajun cuisine, and six hours of music from Japan-based musicians, including Jimmy Angel and bluesman Steve Gardner.</p><p>Gardner, who hails from Mississippi, was back home recording a couple of tracks for his new CD, Big Delta Crossing, when Katrina struck, and had been down in New Orleans appearing on a WWOZ radio program shortly before the hurricane struck.</p><p>Gardner, who has an uncle on the missing list, said of Katrina and Rita: "These tragic things could happen to any of us. We have to try and get over the mental restraints on who and what we are. We've been building a social system that excludes human beings. We need to change that."</p><p>Speaking on upcoming benefits, Gardner said: "The music that came out of New Orleans flowed out through the Mississippi and around the world, embracing us all. And by attending benefits, people can be more than just passive consumers and give a little back."</p><p>For details of the above events see Gig Guide. For information on Hurricane Aid Japan, visit:<url normalizedValue="http://www.hurricane-aid-japan.com">www.hurricane-aid-japan.com</url>. </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">YOMIUR-0509291402</dc:identifier><dc:source urn:contentItem:4H2F-4TT0-00JR-G083-00000-00<published>2005-09-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>U.S. editorial excerpts -5-</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Sept. 7</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Selected editorial excerpts from the U.S. press:</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A FOREIGN AID TWIST: U.S. GETS, OTHERS GIVE (USA Today, McLean, Virginia)</p><p nitf:lede="true"> World reaction to Hurricane Katrina has been like viewing the USA through a Hall of Mirrors. To believe some commentary in countries from Europe to Asia to the Middle East, the world's wealthy superpower has, in Katrina's wake, been exposed as a vulnerable supermonster.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> In this view from abroad, the USA is a place that is callous toward its poor and black. A Pakistani newspaper wrote, for example, of how the U.S. government 'for three days sat smugly apathetic to the people's plight.'</p><p>It's a place where the early looting reflects a culture of violence and selfishness: 'The darker side of the American dream' was how a columnist for London's Daily Mail put it.</p><p> And it's a place where a focus on the Iraq war has starved it of resources to deal with natural disasters -- a favorite topic in the Arab media.</p><p> Accepting Hurricane Katrina aid with grace can't magically make the United States popular, particularly when it comes to sworn U.S. enemies. Some in the Muslim world, for example, are portraying Katrina as God's wrath, as are some thoughtless Christian leaders here.</p><p> Four years ago this weekend, after the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington, the world had a very different reaction to the U.S. distress. Besides offers of help, the world was united with Americans. As a headline in France's Le Monde newspaper trumpeted: 'We Are All Americans.'</p><p> Recalling that more pure generosity -- of spirit and practical help -- is heartening. It's a reminder that, not so long ago, the world saw the United States much as it likes to think of itself: as a generous-spirited, socially-responsible beacon of democracy.</p><p> Regaining that cleareyed international admiration is an ideal. The international response to Hurricane Katrina provides an opening. (Sept. 7)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4H2F-XM30-001X-J4VS-00000-00<published>2005-09-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Pg. 4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>The bitter lessons of Katrina</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Masaharu Asaba / Yomiuri Shimbun Senior Writer</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Footage of the damage produced by Hurricane Katrina looks like scenes from a developing country.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But the hurricane, which devastated large parts of the Gulf Coast of the United States, also gives us valuable lessons in disaster prevention.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The central part of New Orleans, which experienced unprecedented flooding, lies below sea level. The city stands on an accretion of sand from the Mississippi River and is encircled with levees to protect this reclaimed land.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Yomiuri</p></bodyText></section><p>Many African-American and low-income residents, who account for 80 percent of the city's population, lacked cars in which to evacuate and so were trapped in the city.</p><p>On average, the Mississippi River bursts its banks every 10 years. In the Great Flood of 1993, levees broke along a 1,000-kilometer stretch of river upstream from New Orleans. This time, the defenses that protect the residential areas of the city were breached for the first time.</p><p>"Houses were suddenly hit by runoff from the deluge, which was similar to a disaster caused by a flash flood as is often seen in developed countries," Prof. Nobuyuki Tamai of Kanazawa University graduate school said.</p><p>U.S. water policy has focused on building embankments to contain water physically. But a 1994 federal government report warned, "The embankments have induced people to settle down in areas at high risk of flood."</p><p>Every time the United States has been hit by major floods, legal measures--such as the 1968 National Flood Insurance Act and the 1993 Flood Buy-out Program--have been introduced to buy out flood-damaged houses and areas, and to promote the relocation of residents in flood-prone areas.</p><p>However, only 2,000 households have relocated in Louisiana in the two years since the start of the program. The relocation scheme has mainly been used by wealthy people who can afford to buy their own houses.</p><p>Low-income people tend to live in areas at high risk from disasters, as is the case in developed countries in Africa and Asia. According to a research institute at the Catholic University of Louvain in Belgium, of the 170,000 people worldwide who died in floods in the past 25 years, 50 percent were low-income earners, while high-income earners accounted for only 1 percent. Predictably, it is low-wage earners--who cannot afford to take disaster-prevention measures--who are hardest hit by hurricanes.</p><p>However, the administration of President George W. Bush has made the war on terrorism its No. 1 priority, slashing the budget for disaster prevention, which resulted in a slow initial response to Hurricane Katrina. U.S. media criticized the administration, saying the disaster was a "man-made calamity."</p><p>Hurricane Katrina has left valuable lessons in its wake for Japan, which is regularly hit by floods.</p><p>First, we should learn the importance of safety management for minor rivers.</p><p>The embankments along the main channel of the Mississippi River are required to meet stringent standards and prevent a major flood that may happen only once in every 500 years. The levees destroyed by Hurricane Katrina were built to lower safety standards capable of preventing a 1-in-100-years flood.</p><p>In Japan, record rainfalls in Niigata and Fukui prefectures in 2004 breached embankments managed by local governments at 26 points along minor or "second-class" rivers as defined by the river law. Banks built to lower safety standards should be reinforced as quickly as possible.</p><p>Second, the disaster in New Orleans makes obvious the necessity of multiple antidisaster measures.</p><p>Since natural disasters often end up exceeding expected levels of intensity, we cannot rely solely on embankments. "We have to devise multiple countermeasures with flood control reservoirs, underground water tanks, display hazard maps to indicate flood-prone areas and so on. We should put priority on preventing casualties at least," said Hideaki Oda, secretary general of the Japan Water Forum, a Tokyo-based think tank.</p><p>Some scientists estimate that global warming will lead to more typhoons and hurricanes. Hurricane Katrina might be a painful warning from Mother Nature to Bush, who has denied the existence of global warming.</p><p>The United Nations estimates the number of people exposed to the risk of flooding will double to 2 billion in 2050. Therefore, we have to be even more on our guard against the threat.</p><p>Some areas in Tokyo and Saitama Prefecture were flooded Sunday by rainfall that exceeded 100 millimeters in an hour as Typhoon No. 14 approached the Japanese archipelago. We must keep in mind that disasters hit the weakest part of cities.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4H1C-4BP0-00JR-G4ST-00000-00<published>2005-09-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Japan gov't, firms join relief effort for U.S. hurricane victims</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, Sept. 2</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The Japanese government will provide $200,000 in cash to the American Red Cross and offer up to $300,000 worth of tents, blankets and other supplies for victims of Hurricane Katrina, Chief Cabinet Secretary Hiroyuki Hosoda said Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Japanese automakers have also announced emergency aid packages, with Toyota Motor Corp. pledging a total of $5 million to support activities of the Red Cross and the Friedkin Disaster Relief Fund.</p><p>Nissan Motor Co. said it and its employees will offer a total of $750,000 and 50 pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles for Red Cross workers.</p><p> Other Japanese companies followed suit. Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. said it will provide a total of $1 million in relief assistance together with its local subsidiaries. Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. said it will supply 20 million yen in relief money and 15 floodlights powered by portable generators.</p><p> On Friday, the Japanese Red Cross Society decided to provide $200,000 to its U.S. counterpart.</p><p> Hurricane Katrina ripped through the southeastern United States on Monday, leaving New Orleans flooded and without power. Much of Mississippi's coast was laid waste.</p><p> It is feared the death toll in New Orleans will reach into the thousands.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4H3T-4F70-002V-11XW-00000-00<published>2005-09-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:32Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Dollar Moves Narrowly vs. Yen in Tokyo Morning</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>Tokyo, Sept. 14</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The dollar moved narrowly around 110.50 yen in Tokyo Wednesday morning as players hesitated to make major bets amid uncertainty about the future course of the Federal Reserve's credit-tightening campaign.</p><p nitf:lede="true">At noon, the greenback stood at 110.49-51 yen, against 110.48-51 yen at 5 p.m. Tuesday, after moving between 110.42 yen and 110.82 yen.</p><p>The euro was quoted at 1.2294-2296 dollars, against 1.2297-2299 dollars late Tuesday.</p><p>The dollar was firmer above 110.50 yen in early trading here after briefly topping 111 yen in overseas trading overnight on buying triggered by a smaller-than-expected U.S. trade deficit for July.</p><p>But it soon grew top-heavy and hovered without a clear direction for much of the morning trading amid lingering jitters about the Federal Reserve's policy-setting meeting next Tuesday.</p><p>"Expectations for the Fed's continued interest rate hikes ebbed dramatically in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, but some of the expectations have been restored on the market," Junya Tanase, foreign exchange strategist at J.P. Morgan Chase Bank in Tokyo, noted.</p><p>"Still, the market has yet to reach a conclusion on the issue," he said, adding that players will keep close tabs on U.S. economic indicators for September in a bid to gauge the economic impact of Hurricane Katrina, which hit the U.S. Gulf Coast late last month. <br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4H6G-DRF0-00JR-G0B7-00000-00<published>2005-09-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:32Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bush says ready to again release oil reserves, urges conservation</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>WASHINGTON, Sept. 26</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">U.S. President George W. Bush said Monday the government is ready to again tap into strategic oil reserves and to take other actions to deal with fuel shortages and high gasoline prices after Hurricane Rita hit the Gulf area following Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> While reassuring his commitments, Bush also urged American people to help tackle the situation by conserving energy and vowed to work on such longer-term measures such as expanding the oil refining infrastructure and promoting nuclear power generation.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> 'A lot of our production comes from the Gulf, and when you have a Hurricane Katrina followed by Hurricane Rita, it's natural, unfortunately, that it's going to affect supply,' Bush said in acknowledging the storm impact on energy supply after being briefed about the situation at the Energy Department.</p><p>But Bush stressed at a press conference, 'It's important for our people to know that we understand the situation and that we're willing to use the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to mitigate any shortfalls in crude oil that could affect our consumers.'</p><p> The government decided to release the strategic reserves soon after Hurricane Katrina hit the Gulf Coast oil refineries last month in sending gasoline prices sharply higher to the $3 level per gallon.</p><p> Bush said the government will also continue to waive environmental restrictions on fuel blends as well as prohibitions on foreign tankers transporting gasoline between U.S. ports.</p><p> Urging the American people to save energy, Bush said, 'We can all pitch in by being better conservers of energy. I mean, people just need to recognize that the storms have caused disruption and that if they're able to maybe not drive when they -- on a trip that's not essential, that would helpful.'</p><p> Bush said the hurricanes underlined the need for the United States to boost its refining capacity and to seek alternative energy sources such as nuclear power.</p><p> 'The storms have shown how fragile the balance is between supply and demand in America,' he said. 'We need more refining capacity, and I look forward to working with Congress as we analyze the energy situation to expedite the capacity of our refiners to expand and/or build new refineries.'</p><p> 'I've often said one of the worst problems we have is that we're dependent on foreign sources of crude oil,' Bush said. 'It is clear that when you're dependent upon natural gas and/or hydrocarbons to fuel your economy and that supply gets disrupted, we need alternative sources of energy.'</p><p> 'That's why I believe so strongly in nuclear power,' Bush said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4H16-MJW0-002V-11H8-00000-00<published>2005-09-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:32Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Japan Firms to Extend Aid for U.S. Hurricane Victims</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>Tokyo, Sept. 2</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">An increasing number of Japanese companies are planning to extend aid to support the victims of Hurricane Katrina that has struck the U.S. Gulf Coast.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Toyota Motor Corp. <7203> has announced a plan to provide 5 million dollars of aid, including 2 million dollars to be donated to the American Red Cross.</p><p>Nissan Motor Co. <7201> will contribute up to one million dollars, including donations from its U.S. employees. It will also supply the state government of Mississippi with 50 pickup trucks for transportation of aid supplies.</p><p>Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. <6752>, Canon Inc. <7751> and Toshiba Corp. <6502> will each extend one million dollars. Toshiba will also supply medical equipment.</p><p>Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. <7011> will supply 15 units of lighting equipment, worth 10 million yen, and 20 million yen in cash.</p><p>Brother Industries Ltd. <6448>, a maker of printers, copiers and sewing machines, will donate 15 million yen.</p><p>Among drug makers, Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. <4502> will donate about 20 million yen in cash and Astellas Pharma Inc. <4503> will provide medicines worth 50,000 dollars.</p><p>Major traders Itochu Corp. <8001>, Sumitomo Corp. <8053> and Marubeni Corp. <8002> will provide 10,000 to 50,000 dollars.</p><p>The Japan Business Federation, the biggest business lobby known as Nippon Keidanren, is considering collecting donations from member companies.</p><p>Hurricane Katrina is seen to have possibly killed thousands of people in what could be the deadliest natural disaster in the United States in a century. <br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IEA to release 2 mil. barrels per day in hurricane aftermath</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>PARIS, Sept. 3</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The International Energy Agency said Friday it has decided to release 2 million barrels of oil per day from strategic reserves in the wake of Hurricane Katrina which ripped through U.S. Gulf Coast states, the International Energy Agency said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> 'All 26 IEA member countries will take collective action in response to the interrupted oil supplies in the Gulf of Mexico caused by Hurricane Katrina,' IEA Executive Director Claude Mandil said.</p><p>'The loss of production in the Gulf of Mexico and considerable damage to oil refining and transportation infrastructure constitute a serious disruption of supplies.'</p><p> It is the first time in 14 years for the IEA to tap members' reserves since 1991 when it tried to curb soaring oil at the time of Gulf War.</p><p> The IEA said its member countries and the European Commission, the executive body of the European Union, unanimously back the measure to make available to the market the equivalent of 2 million barrels per day of oil for an initial period of 30 days.</p><p> The world energy watchdog said the United States has lost 1.5 million barrels per day of oil production and 2 million barrels a day of refining capacity. The group's support will help make up those losses, it said.</p><p> 'Although the initial impact of the storm was regional, the implications for the oil market are global,' the IEA said. 'IEA member countries are acting in solidarity with the United States in addressing this loss and restoring confidence to the oil market. IEA member countries are aware that products and, in particular, gasoline, will be the most useful contribution.'</p><p> The IEA may consider further help after examining the effects of the first round of emergency release, it added.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4H5V-H6K0-00JR-G00S-00000-00<published>2005-09-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Houston residents seek shelter as Hurricane Rita nears</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>HOUSTON, Sept. 23</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">With the arrival of Hurricane Rita less than 24 hours away, the streets of Houston, Texas, are all but deserted.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Those who remain -- many of them homeless -- are hoping to find safe shelter in which to ride out the storm.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Houston is home to two million people, and by Thursday the majority of them had left town in a mass exodus that dwarfed the evacuation of New Orleans before Hurricane Katrina.</p><p>The city's Main Street, lined with stores and restaurants and usually buzzing with activity, was eerily quiet for a weekday afternoon.</p><p> Paolo Semenzato was in line at the one open grocery store on Main Street. He was trying to buy a case of bottled water, but was matter-of-fact about what he really needed.</p><p> 'What do I need right now? Right now I need about a house,' he said.</p><p> Semenzato, 40, is one of many low-income Houston residents without a secure place to weather the storm. He said he would try to find refuge at a Salvation Army shelter but was not overly optimistic.</p><p> 'I'm underneath the bridge right about now,' he said. 'They got about 18 homeless people underneath that bridge right downtown, and they have nowhere to go.'</p><p> Calvin Haley, 43, was also unsure about where he would spend the next several nights. He said his primary concern was finding a location that would remain high and dry throughout the hurricane.</p><p> 'We just got to find a spot to get into, a higher ground spot, that's about all of it,' he said. For him, the safest option seemed to be on one of the high freeway bridges that leads out of the downtown area.</p><p> Haley said he did not have enough food or water to ride out the hurricane. The one store still open on Main Street was of little use to those without money to buy anything.</p><p> 'I asked for some water, but they're not giving that away,' he said.</p><p> Of the situation facing Houston's homeless community, Haley made a grim prediction. 'We're just going to have a starvation,' he said.</p><p> There was activity in at least one Houston location Thursday. The George R. Brown Convention Center, used until earlier this week as a shelter for victims of Hurricane Katrina, has been opened for local evacuees.</p><p> Francine Bailey, 49, was waiting to enter the facility after she and her family left their home in a low-lying area of Houston.</p><p> 'It floods real bad over there, and we knew that if it rains, it's going to flood,' she said.</p><p> Bailey said it was the first time she had evacuated her home, a decision she made after watching news coverage of the approaching storm. She declined to say whether her caution was the result of seeing the devastation in New Orleans from Hurricane Katrina.</p><p> 'I just want to make sure my kids are safe,' she said.</p><p> With time running out before Hurricane Rita makes landfall, Houston residents unable to evacuate are seeking safety anywhere they can.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4H1C-4BP0-00JR-G4VX-00000-00<published>2005-09-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Japan to free oil stockpile equal to 12% of IEA's planned release</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, Sept. 3</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Japan will free part of its private-sector oil stockpile at an amount equal to 12 percent of the International Energy Agency's planned release of 60 million barrels following Hurricane Katrina, government officials said Saturday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Japan last tapped its oil stockpile in 1991 during the Gulf War as part of world efforts to curb soaring oil prices.</p><p>The timing of the release of the oil will be decided in view of similar moves by other IEA members, the officials said, adding it could be in the next week at the earliest.</p><p> The IEA requires each of its members to maintain oil reserves equivalent to at least 90 days worth of consumption.</p><p> As of June 30, Japan had oil reserves equivalent to 170 days worth of its consumption, comprising the private-sector stockpile of about 79 days and the state oil stockpile of about 91 days, according to the officials.</p><p> About 50 percent of the private-sector reserves are already in the form of oil products easier to release in an emergency, they said. The state stockpile has never been tapped.</p><p> The Paris-based IEA said Friday its 26 members had agreed to release the equivalent of 2 million barrels of oil per day from their strategic reserves for an initial period of 30 days as part of the global response to help the oil market deal with the effects of the powerful hurricane.</p><p> Hurricane Katrina ripped through U.S. Gulf Coast states, ravaging oil production facilities and sending crude oil futures to a record high of more than $70 per barrel earlier this week.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Dollar falls to lower end of 109 yen in Tokyo morning deals</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, Sept. 5</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The U.S. dollar fell to the lower end of 109 yen Monday morning in Tokyo as damage from Hurricane Katrina and high crude oil prices continued to put downward pressure on the currency.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> At noon, the dollar was quoted at 109.16-18 yen, down from Friday's 5 p.m. quotes of 109.76-86 yen in New York and 109.55-57 yen in Tokyo.</p><p>It traded between 109.10 yen and 109.80 yen during the morning.</p><p> The euro was quoted at $1.2576-2578 and 137.29-33 yen, against Friday's 5 p.m. quotes of $1.2525-2535 and 137.42-52 yen in New York and $1.2536-2538 and 137.34-38 yen in Tokyo.</p><p> The dollar maintained the upper 109 yen level in early morning trading, but lost ground as Japanese banks sold the dollar for the yen, dealers said.</p><p> Some traders were also seen selling the dollar for the yen, in line with the U.S. currency's fall against the euro.</p><p> A weak dollar trend has been dominant in the market as market players are worried that the U.S. Federal Reserve might suspend its drive to raise interest rates because of the possible negative impact of Hurricane Katrina and soaring oil prices on the U.S. economy, dealers said.</p><p> 'The market cannot erase those concerns over the U.S. economy,' said Kazuhiro Nishina, manager of derivative marketing group 1 of Aozora Bank. 'Such concerns are likely to put more pressure on the dollar.'</p><p> The market did not react to an early Monday report by the Japanese government that corporate capital spending in the April-June quarter rose from a year earlier for the ninth consecutive quarter, dealers said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4H15-BHP0-00JR-G4MR-00000-00<published>2005-09-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>U.S. editorial excerpts -4-</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Sept. 1</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Selected editorial excerpts from the U.S. press:</p><p nitf:lede="true"> POWERLESS AGAINST NATURE (Los Angeles Times, Los Angeles)</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Television news programs have conveyed the havoc and the heartbreak caused by Hurricane Katrina in New Orleans and surrounding areas. Thousands are missing or dead, millions have been forced from their homes and billions of dollars worth of property has been destroyed.</p><p>Among the most notable impacts is the reduced supply of gasoline, fuel oil and natural gas, which in turn increase the pressure for a more sensible national energy policy.</p><p> The disruption of the Gulf drilling platforms and pipelines could mean that less natural gas will be socked away for the winter, when the need is greatest. The country amassed a healthy surplus early this year, but most of that cushion has been consumed by power plants during the unusually hot summer months.</p><p> There's no quick fix for the looming problems with the supply of natural gas. Because there are so few places to stockpile liquid natural gas - only five in the United States - we cannot simply import the stuff from a foreign producer to replace what we're losing from the Gulf.</p><p> Liquid natural gas storage facilities are controversial; a proposal to put one in Long Beach Harbor has drawn fierce resistance.</p><p> Hurricane Katrina has created far more urgent challenges, of course, which President Bush outlined in his remarks to the nation Wednesday. But one of the problems Katrina has exposed is not just the vulnerability of the Gulf's energy supplies but the need for a comprehensive energy plan that relies on more varied sources of energy. (Sept. 1)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4H6H-SBG0-002V-1039-00000-00<published>2005-09-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Dollar Surges to 2-Month Highs vs. Yen in Tokyo</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>Tokyo, Sept. 27</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The dollar surged to two-month highs just below 113 yen in Tokyo Tuesday, reflecting players' renewed expectations for the U.S. Federal Reserve's continued rate hike campaign.</p><p nitf:lede="true">At 5 p.m., the greenback stood at 112.90-93 yen, up from 112.50-53 yen at the same time Monday, after climbing as high as 112.98 yen, a level unseen here since July 20.</p><p>It touched a low of 112.18 yen early in the morning. The U.S. unit traded most frequently at 112.70 yen, against Monday's 112.37 yen.</p><p>The dollar also spurted against the euro. Europe's common currency slipped as low as 1.1992 dollars, before being quoted at 1.2012-2015 dollars, down from 1.2040-2043 dollars late Monday, and at 135.64-68 yen, against 135.48-52 yen.</p><p>After showing range-bound moves in overseas trading overnight, the dollar gathered upward momentum in Tokyo shortly after the midmorning's local rate fixings as Japanese commercial players stepped up buying.</p><p>The U.S. unit came within a whisker of 113 yen in late dealings, but failed to break above the line due to bouts of profit-taking and sell orders from Japanese exporters.</p><p>"The market now has a similar level of expectations for the Fed's continued rate hikes as it did before Hurricane Katrina hit the United States," Junya Tanase, foreign exchange market strategist at J.P. Morgan Chase Bank in Tokyo, said.</p><p>Tanase noted that Monday's remarks by Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Michael Moskow and Kansas City Fed President Thomas Hoenig, who both played down the damage from Hurricane Katrina and Hurricane Rita on the U.S. economy, underpinned the market's rate expectations.</p><p>Currency players now await U.S. consumer confidence data for September to be released by the Conference Board later in the day. Many traders said that weak readings have already been factored into the market. <br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4H21-21W0-00JR-G52G-00000-00<published>2005-09-06T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Dollar hovers in lower 109 yen level in Tokyo morning</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, Sept. 6</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The U.S. dollar hovered in the lower 109 yen level Tuesday morning in Tokyo as Japanese importers bought it, though others sold it on concern about the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina in the United States.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> At noon, the dollar was quoted at 109.22-25 yen, compared with 109.10-20 yen at 4 p.m. Monday in London and 109.21-23 yen at 5 p.m. Monday in Tokyo. U.S. markets were closed Monday for the Labor Day holiday.</p><p>The dollar traded between 109.13 yen and 109.54 yen in the morning.</p><p> The euro was quoted at $1.2495-2498 and 136.48-52 yen, against $1.2510-2520 and 136.60-65 yen at 4 p.m. Monday in London and $1.2536-2538 and 136.91-95 yen at 5 p.m. Monday in Tokyo.</p><p> After falling to a two-month low in the upper 108 yen level overnight in London, the U.S. currency, bought by Japanese importers, rose to the mid-109 yen level in the early morning in Tokyo.</p><p> After Japan's key Nikkei stock index ended the morning session up 0.67 percent at a four-year high of 12,719.50, the dollar fell to a low of 109.13 yen as the yen was bought.</p><p> Dealers said the good performance of Japanese stocks encouraged currency traders to buy the yen. But its upside was limited due to uncertainty about the results of Japan's general election Sunday, they said.</p><p> 'Some importers initially showed interest in buying the dollar because it fell to the 108 yen level overseas,' said Akihiro Tanaka, planning manager in Resona Bank's market trading division.</p><p> 'But a possible pause in interest rate hikes by the U.S. Federal Reserve due to damage to the U.S. economy from Hurricane Katrina and the good performance of Japanese stocks prompted investors to buy the yen and sell the dollar,' he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier
