urn:contentItem:4H38-W3G0-00JR-G0SD-00000-00<published>2005-09-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>U.S. marks 4th anniversary of terrorist attacks</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Sept. 11</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Americans on Sunday marked the fourth anniversary of the 2001 terrorist attacks on the United States in ceremonies overshadowed by the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> In New York, an anniversary ceremony began at 8:46 a.m., the exact time the first hijacked plane struck the World Trade Center's North Tower.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It was the first of four moments of silence to mark the times the planes hit each tower and the times each tower collapsed.</p><p>During the ceremony, siblings of victims read the names of the deceased at Ground Zero.</p><p> President George W. Bush also observed a moment of silence.</p><p> On Friday, Bush posthumously awarded the 9/11 Heroes Medal of Valor to the families of 442 public safety officials who died four years ago trying to save other people.</p><p> In a weekly radio address on Saturday, Bush said, 'Four years later, Americans remember the fears and uncertainty and confusion of that terrible morning.'</p><p> However, this year's 9/11 anniversary ceremonies took place as the country has been struggling to deal with another crisis triggered by Hurricane Katrina.</p><p> 'Today, America is confronting another disaster that has caused destruction and loss of life,' he said in his radio address. 'Once more our hearts ache for our fellow citizens, and many are left with questions about the future. Yet we are again being reminded that adversity brings out the best in the American spirit.'</p><p> On the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, two hijacked commercial jetliners crashed into the World Trade Center's twin towers and another hijacked plane hit the Pentagon outside Washington. A fourth hijacked plane crashed in Pennsylvania.</p><p> About 3,000 people died in the attacks. Among the victims were 24 Japanese nationals, including two who were aboard two of the four ill-fated airlines.</p><p> The attacks led the Bush administration to wage a global war on terror and invade Iraq.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4H38-W3H0-00JR-G0YR-00000-00<published>2005-09-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>METI welcomes industry's oil stock release</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, Sept. 12</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Vice Economy, Trade and Industry Minister Hideji Sugiyama on Monday welcomed moves by Japanese oil firms to tap into their oil reserves in response to the government's calls last week to allay global supply concerns in the wake of Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> 'I see news reports of the industry's efforts to release oil stocks and believe they understand the government's initiative,' Sugiyama said at a press conference. He added the government will stay in close contact with the firms to ensure that freeing up oil reserves has the intended effect.</p><p>The government has requested oil firms to release a total of 7.3 billion barrels over 30 days to address the supply shortage.</p><p> Economy, Trade and Industry Minister Shoichi Nakagawa announced last Tuesday Japan will release more than 200,000 barrels a day in the form of either crude oil or petroleum products from reserves held by 66 private-sector firms as part of an International Energy Agency initiative.</p><p> To increase supplies to the market, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry lowered the private-sector oil stockpile minimum from 70 days' supplies to 67 days.</p><p>Exxon Mobil Corp. said last Thursday it plans to export 22,000 kiloliters of alkylate, used to produce gasoline, to the United States early next month and 100,000 kl of diesel oil to Europe later this month in response to global supply concerns.</p><p> On Sept. 2, the Paris-based IEA said its 26 members will free a total of 2 million barrels from their strategic oil reserves per day for the initial period of 30 days, after the hurricane that severely damaged oil production facilities along the U.S. Gulf Coast.</p><p>Japan is responsible for releasing 12.2 percent of the 60-million barrel total. The IEA will review the impact of its coordinated action on Thursday.</p><p> Hurricane Katrina has cost 57.0 percent of oil production in the Gulf of Mexico. Crude oil production in the Gulf will likely be reduced by 140,000 barrels per day this year as a result of the hurricane, according to the IEA.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4H1C-4BP0-00JR-G4TX-00000-00<published>2005-09-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>U.S. editorial excerpts 2-</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Sept. 2</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Selected editorial excerpts from the U.S. press:</p><p nitf:lede="true"> FROM BAD TO WORSE (The Washington Post, Washington)</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The humanitarian disaster and the disintegration of public order in New Orleans are clearly outstripping the government's inadequate resources on the ground. Help is on the way in the form of thousands of desperately needed National Guardsmen, whose presence around the city was becoming slightly more visible as of yesterday afternoon.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But the sluggish initial response to one of the nation's most devastating natural disasters has embittered and inflamed tens of thousands of people still awaiting relief, most of them poor and black and many of them old and sick. The Crescent City, a carefree mecca of wild parties, rich food and pretty architecture, has become a national tragedy.</p><p>The hardship and suffering that attended Hurricane Katrina when it lashed the city Monday morning had devolved by yesterday into something between a disaster zone and a state of nature: Officials said thousands may be dead; shots reportedly were fired at a rescue helicopter and a hospital trying to evacuate its patients; trash fires burned and fecal matter befouled the city; looters and carjackers, some of them armed, have run rampant.</p><p> When the mayhem is contained, the refugees are evacuated and the dead are counted, New Orleanians themselves are certain to demand some explanations, and they deserve answers. The nation had heaved a sigh of relief early Monday when Hurricane Katrina hit, believing New Orleans had been spared the worst when the storm veered just to the east of town as it made landfall.</p><p> But how could the government have been so unready for a crisis that was so widely predicted? It is simply not true, as Mr. Bush said yesterday, that nobody 'anticipated the breach of the levees.'</p><p> In fact, experts inside and outside of government have issued repeated warnings for years about the city's unique topography and vulnerability, and those warnings were loudly and prominently echoed by the media both nationally and in Louisiana. How is it possible that city, state and federal authorities lacked an emergency plan that could be quickly activated? (Sept. 2)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Energy measures, trade imbalances to highlight G-7 talks: U.S.</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>WASHINGTON, Sept. 21</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">U.S. Treasury Secretary John Snow will urge Japan, Europe and Asia to boost their economic growth during the Group of Seven financial meeting on Friday which will highlight energy measures and trade imbalances, a senior Treasury official said Wednesday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Snow will explain that Hurricane Katrina's impact on the U.S. economy will be 'noticeable, but short-lived,' with rebuilding activities 'likely to boost growth in early 2006,' U.S. Treasury Undersecretary for International Affairs Timothy Adams told reporters.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But noting that energy supply disruptions 'put a damper on growth' by raising prices, Adams said the G-7 finance ministers and central bank governors will discuss 'steps taken to address supply and efficiency issues as well as technical measures such as the improvement of data availability.'</p><p nitf:lede="true"> 'Higher oil prices are also causing problems for some emerging markets, particularly those that control domestic prices at low levels,' Adams said.</p><p>The top financial meeting of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States comes after Hurricane Katrina devastated the U.S. Gulf area late last month, including the oil refining infrastructure there, which has sent gasoline prices sharply higher.</p><p> The G-7 meeting will also focus on measures to deal with swelling global trade imbalances, Adams said, adding that they, along with the energy problem, pose 'risks' for the global economy, which has been growing 'strongly with the outlook positive going forward.'</p><p> Snow 'will underscore the need for action also in the rest of the world to address imbalances,' Adams said. 'This means more labor and product market reform in Europe and Japan, more financial sector and corporate reform in Asia, and greater exchange rate flexibility.'</p><p> 'We need significantly more domestic demand-led growth from other parts of the world,' Adams said, calling it 'hard to see growth in major industrial countries rising much above 2 percent, perhaps not even 1.75 percent' at this time.</p><p> 'The United States has no current account target and will not set one,' he said. 'Nor will we slow growth simply to correct external imbalances.'</p><p> 'What is needed is not less growth in the United States, but more engines of growth from more countries and new reforms to appreciably boost potential growth rates,' Adams said.</p><p> Snow will reaffirm the U.S. commitments to halving its budget deficit by fiscal 2009, Adams said, stressing the U.S. economy 'can absorb the cost' of emergency spending in the wake of Hurricane Katrina.</p><p> As for China's shift in July to a more flexible exchange rate regime, Adams said the United States expects Beijing to adopt greater flexibility 'over time.'</p><p> But Adams refused to say if Washington is dissatisfied by the recent Chinese move and wants Beijing to take swifter action.</p><p> 'We supported the move,' he said. 'But implied in that support is an expectation that they will indeed follow through on what they've said, and what they continue to say, which is greater flexibility over time.'</p><p> 'I take them at their word. I have no reason to doubt them at this time,' Adams said. But the United States is monitoring it 'very, very closely.'</p><p> Chinese Foreign Minister Jin Renqing and People's Bank of China Governor Zhou Xiaochuan are slated to take part in a working lunch that the G-7 nations have arranged for talks with Brazil, China, Russia and South Africa.</p><p> Adams said the G-7 ministers and central bankers will also discuss debt relief for poor countries, reform of the International Monetary Fund, the Doha round of multilateral trade negotiations under the World Trade Organization, and measures to cut off terrorist financing.</p><p> The G-7 meeting will be followed by a series of semiannual international financial gatherings this weekend under the IMF and the World Bank.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4KV7-HBJ0-TX7H-P35B-00000-00Mazda6 Marks Three-Millionth Vehicle Produced at Autoalliance International-Mazda North American Operations Donates Mazda6 to Habitat for Humanity2006-09-07T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:18:33ZLexisNexisMazda6 Marks Three-Millionth Vehicle Produced at Autoalliance International-Mazda North American Operations Donates Mazda6 to Habitat for HumanityHiroshima, Japan

Hiroshima, Sept 7, 2006 - (JCN Newswire) - Mazda North American Operations (MNAO) announced on September 6, 2006, that the Mazda6 will be the three-millionth vehicle produced at AutoAlliance International, Inc. (AAI) plant in Flat Rock, Michigan. MNAO will donate the three-millionth vehicle, a Volcanic Red Mazda6 5-Door, to the victims of Hurricane Katrina through the New Orleans Area Habitat for Humanity(R). Last year AAI raised $25,000 to support the victims of Hurricane Katrina.

Mazda first began producing vehicles in the U.S. in 1987 at its MazdaMotor Manufacturing (USA) Corporation (MMUC) in Flat Rock, Michigan. In 1992, MMUC changed its name to AAI and formed an equal partnership between Mazda and Ford. Today, AAI is a plant that employs more than 3,700 workers. Past products produced at AAI include the Mazda MX-6, Mazda 626, Ford Probe and Mercury Cougar. Currently AAI produces the Mazda6 and Ford Mustang.

"Mazda's partnership with the AAI facility spans nearly 20 years," said Jim O'Sullivan, president and CEO, Mazda North American Operations. "We couldn't be more thrilled to mark this new milestone with one of our own."

Habitat for Humanity is a worldwide ecumenical Christian housing ministry that works to develop communities for people in need by building and renovating houses so there are houses in decent communities in which every person can live.

About Mazda Motor Corporation

Mazda Motor Corporation (TSE: 7261) started manufacturing tools in 1929 and soon branched out into production of trucks for commercial use. In the early 1960s, Mazda launched its first passenger car models and began developing rotary engines. Still headquartered in Hiroshima in western Japan, Mazda today ranks as one of Japan's leading automakers, and exports cars to the United States and Europe for over 30 years. Overseas sales account for more than half of total turnover. Mazda has two main production sites in Japan and 19 overseas facilities. Overseas sites include joint ventures based in the United States, and in Thailand with Ford Motor Company, Mazda's largest shareholder.

urn:contentItem:4H9S-7MT0-00JR-G2RR-00000-00<published>2005-10-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>U.S. editorial excerpts</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Oct. 12</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Selected editorial excerpts from the U.S. press:</p><p nitf:lede="true"> THE KASHMIR EARTHQUAKE (The Washington Post, Washington)</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The news from earthquake-stricken Pakistan gets steadily worse. Initially the death toll was estimated at 20,000, making the disaster 20 times more lethal than Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But yesterday an army official close to the rescue operations revised it up to between 35,000 and 40,000, with 2,000 more fatalities likely across the border in Indian-controlled Kashmir. This is nothing like the Asian tsunami, which killed an estimated 230,000; nor does it approach the scale of the Bangladeshi cyclone that killed about 140,000 in 1991.</p><p>But the provincial capital of Muzaffarabad has been reduced to almost nothing. At least 2 million people are homeless, and winter is just weeks away.</p><p> The response -- or at least the announced response -- has been generous and fast. The United Nations issued an appeal for $272 million yesterday, but its call appeared almost redundant: Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates have each promised $100 million worth of assistance; the Bush administration, which was slow off the mark after the tsunami as well as after Hurricane Katrina, has already pledged an initial $50 million.</p><p> Aid missions of various kinds have reportedly arrived from Britain, China, South Korea, Turkey, Spain, Iran, Russia, the Netherlands, Japan and Germany. The first U.S. transport plane loaded with blankets and other relief supplies landed in the afflicted region on Monday.</p><p> If there is any silver lining to this tragedy, it's that it may shock people into fresh thinking. This can lead to innovations, such as insurance schemes that create incentives to build in safer places, or it can lead to geopolitical progress.</p><p>Greece offered help after Turkey's 1999 earthquake, beginning the diplomatic thaw between these traditional enemies. After the Kashmir earthquake, India offered aid that Pakistan accepted. Perhaps this gesture may accelerate the reconciliation between India and Pakistan.</p><p> No matter what progress may come, the earthquake certainly was too high a price to pay. 'For the first two days we have been either digging ground to recover bodies or digging to bury them,' Sikander Hayat Khan, the highest-ranking elected official in Pakistani-controlled Kashmir, told Reuters. 'Kashmir has turned into a graveyard.' (Oct. 12)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4HV2-74J0-00JR-G34D-00000-00<published>2005-12-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bill and Melinda Gates, Bono are Time's 2005 'Persons of the Year'</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Dec. 18</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Time magazine said Sunday it has chosen Bill Gates, the world's richest man, and his wife Melinda, as well as Irish rock star Bono as its 2005 'Persons of the Year' for being shrewd about doing good, for rewiring politics and re-engineering justice and for making mercy smarter.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> In its Dec. 19 issue, Managing Editor James Kelly said, 'Natural disasters are terrible things, but what ultimately defines us is not what happens to us but how we react. After the tsunami hit, the world donated billions of dollars; Americans alone gave $1.6 billion, more than to any other disaster overseas. And four months after Hurricane Katrina, the donations approach $3 billion.'</p><p>'This got me to thinking about the nature of giving, and what makes for temporary relief vs. lasting change. Sudden disasters get the big headlines, but day after day other tragedies of avoidable dimensions unfold: the one child who dies of malaria in Africa every 29 seconds, the one person who is infected with HIV every 6.4 seconds, the 8 million who die every year because they are too poor to stay alive.</p><p> 'And who is proving most effective in figuring out how to eradicate those calamities? In different ways, it is Bill and Melinda Gates...and Bono, the Irish rocker who has made debt reduction sexy,' Kelly said.</p><p> Editor-at-large Nancy Gibbs makes the case for their selection: 'For being shrewd about doing good, for rewiring politics and re-engineering justice, for making mercy smarter and hope strategic and then daring the rest of us to follow, Bill and Melinda Gates and Bono are Time's Persons of the Year.'</p><p> 'And so another alliance was born: unlikely, unsentimental, hard nosed, clear eyed and dead set on driving poverty into history. The rocker's job is to be raucous, grab our attention. The engineers' job is to make things work,' Gibbs said. '2005 is the year they turned the corner, when Bono charmed and bullied and morally blackmailed the leaders of the world's richest countries into forgiving $40 billion in debt owed by the poorest.'</p><p> Time also named as 'Partners of the Year' former U.S. Presidents George Bush and Bill Clinton -- the onetime rivals who joined forces to raise relief money for those who suffered in the Asian tsunami and Hurricane Katrina.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4H38-W3G0-00JR-G0SX-00000-00<published>2005-09-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>U.S. marks 4th anniversary of Sept. 11 terrorist attacks</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Sept. 11</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The United States on Sunday marked the fourth anniversary of the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington in ceremonies overshadowed by the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> In New York, an anniversary ceremony began at 8:46 a.m., the time the first hijacked plane struck the North Tower of the World Trade Center.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It was the first of four moments of silence marking the times the two planes hit each tower and the times each tower collapsed.</p><p>As siblings of victims read the names of the 2,749 people killed at Ground Zero, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg said, 'Our hearts turn as well toward London, our sister city,' referring to the July 7 suicide bombings on the transport network.</p><p>U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice also attended the New York ceremony and made brief remarks.</p><p> President George W. Bush observed a moment of silence on the South Lawn of the White House, along with his wife Laura, Vice President Dick Cheney and his wife Lynne. He will leave for New Orleans later in the day.</p><p> Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld led a Pentagon ceremony at Arlington National Cemetery.</p><p> On Friday, Bush awarded the 9/11 Heroes Medal of Valor to the families of 442 public safety officials killed four years ago trying to save other people.</p><p> In a weekly radio address Saturday, Bush said, 'Four years later, Americans remember the fears and uncertainty and confusion of that terrible morning.'</p><p> This year's 9/11 anniversary ceremonies took place as the country struggles to deal with the crisis triggered by Hurricane Katrina.</p><p> 'Today, America is confronting another disaster that has caused destruction and loss of life,' the president said in his radio address. 'Once more our hearts ache for our fellow citizens, and many are left with questions about the future. Yet we are again being reminded that adversity brings out the best in the American spirit.'</p><p> On the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, two hijacked commercial airplanes crashed into the World Trade Center's twin towers and another hijacked plane hit the Pentagon outside Washington. A fourth hijacked plane crashed in a Pennsylvania field.</p><p> The attacks led the Bush administration to wage a global war on terror and invade Iraq.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4H86-6HP0-00JR-G1KC-00000-00<published>2005-10-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bush reiterates need to boost refining capacity</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>WASHINGTON, Oct. 4</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">U.S. President George W. Bush on Tuesday spoke about the need to expand the nation's oil refining capacity to deal with supply shortages, a key energy issue that has gained particular relevance in the wake of hurricanes Katrina and Rita.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Speaking at a White House news conference, Bush called on the U.S. Congress to address the refining issue, with the goal of passing 'reasonable laws that allow current refineries to expand and to encourage the construction of new refineries.'</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Bush said that oil supply disruptions resulting from the recent hurricanes have led to higher gasoline prices, and suggested that expanding refining capacity is the only way to increase supply.</p><p>He pointed to the 'amazing fact' that no new oil refineries have been built in the United States since the 1970s. He stressed the need for better conservation, echoing a call he made in a news conference last week for all Americans to be more prudent consumers of energy.</p><p> The president also spoke about the importance of alternative energy sources, such as solar and nuclear power, as a means to increase energy supply.</p><p> On the subject of the ongoing federal response to Hurricane Katrina, Bush again admitted responsibility for mistakes made by the federal government.</p><p> 'I command a large, vast administration,' he said, adding, 'I'll take all of the responsibility for the failures at the federal level.'</p><p> Bush first made such an admission in a Sept. 13 news conference, in the face of widespread criticism of the Federal Emergency Management Agency and its then director, Michael Brown. Brown was relieved of his Hurricane Katrina response duties on Sept. 9, and resigned as head of FEMA three days later.</p><p> Bush also used the news conference as an opportunity to reaffirm his position on Iraq, an issue he feels is central to the fight against terrorism.</p><p> 'We're making good progress in Iraq. Iraq is part of the war on terror. That's what the American people need to understand,' he said.</p><p> Despite a U.S. death toll nearing 2,000 troops, Bush stressed that continued American commitment in Iraq is a necessary part of what he termed 'a larger global struggle.'</p><p> 'We have to win in Iraq, and we will win in Iraq,' he said.</p><p> Bush began the news conference by reaffirming his confidence in Harriet Miers, whom he nominated Monday to the Supreme Court to replace retiring Justice Sandra Day O'Connor.</p><p> 'She's a woman of principle and deep conviction,' he said, adding later, 'She'll bring credit to the bench and to the law.'</p><p> Members of the political right wing have expressed concern that Miers is not conservative enough, and that her appointment may contribute to a leftward shift in how cases are decided in the nation's highest court.</p><p> Bush said that his belief in Miers' abilities as a jurist, not her views on social issues such as abortion, led to her nomination.</p><p> 'There is no litmus test. What matters to me is her judicial philosophy,' he added.</p><p> The U.S. Senate is expected to confirm Miers' appointment by late November.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4HBV-38X0-00JR-G3BH-00000-00<published>2005-10-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Asian editorial excerpts</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, Oct. 17</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Selected editorial excerpts from the Asia-Pacific press:</p><p nitf:lede="true"> LOOK ELSEWHERE FOR UN NOMINEE (Bangkok Post, Bangkok)</p><p nitf:lede="true"> There is still time to change the Thai candidate for the top job at the United Nations. Rather than bridle at his choice being questioned, Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra should face up to reality and show leadership by calling for a referendum, or at least an independent poll.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It has been evident to this newspaper from almost the word go that Deputy Prime Minister Surakiart Sathirathai does not enjoy public support for the U.N. job.</p><p>The U.N. secretary general faces daunting tasks, the main ones being to resolve conflict, maintain world peace and to fight poverty through sustainable development. Over the past year, the United Nation's duty also to deal with natural disasters, and its ability to mitigate suffering, was put to the test by the Dec. 26 tsunami that devastated large parts of the Indian Ocean Rim including Thailand, Hurricane Katrina that hit the United States and the earthquake that mauled Kashmir.</p><p> On top of these challenges, the U.N.'s helmsman also has to counter criticisms of the organization's relevance, the most vocal of which come from Washington.</p><p> All of these require skill, relevant experience, and integrity. Critics find the current candidate lacking these qualities.</p><p> The conflict in the deep South that has left some 900 deaths in its wake is sufficient failure to disqualify any government candidate.</p><p> As if to make amends, build its donor status, and thereby its international stature, the government has gone almost overboard with handouts, making much of assistance to the United States after Hurricane Katrina struck New Orleans...Many questioned the appropriateness of such largesse given the depleted state of the national coffers.</p><p> But Thailand's success with HIV/AIDS and the bird flu gives the candidate hoping to succeed Kofi Annan a chance. But he or she needs to be seen to have the support of the country as a whole, as well as the goods to do the job.</p><p> The prime minister has plenty of other tools if he does not want to hold a referendum or commission a survey. There is the famous box at his official residence, many radio and television stations, not to mention his weekly Saturday show, which could introduce interactive phone-ins.</p><p> But it boils down to willingness to admit a mistake, and adapt to the truth. If Mr. Thaksin were to look beyond his party, and place his ears close to the ground, he would find plenty of better alternative candidates.</p><p> Restoration of the reputation of the country is at stake. A decision that does not carry the weight of popular support will not achieve it. (Oct. 17)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4H56-KPR0-00JR-G2HG-00000-00<published>2005-09-20T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Fed raises key rate for 11th consecutive rate hike</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>WASHINGTON, Sept. 20</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The U.S. Federal Reserve boosted its key short-term target rate by 0.25 percentage point to 3.75 percent Tuesday, its 11th consecutive rate hike since June late last year, seeing only a temporary impact from Hurricane Katrina and reiterating its readiness to take further action at a 'measured' pace to fend off inflation.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The widely expected step also represented the 11th 0.25 point rate hike in the target for the federal funds rate since June 30 last year, when the U.S. central bank raised the target to 1.25 percent from a 46-year low of 1.0 percent.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> At the end of a one-day meeting of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee, Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan and eight other members voted to boost the closely watched rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans. The board's 10th and last member voted against it in favor of keeping the target rate unchanged.</p><p>The Fed also raised the more symbolic discount rate, which the central bank charges on loans to commercial banks, by 0.25 point to 4.75 percent.</p><p> The move came amid soaring gasoline and other energy prices after Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans and other Gulf areas late last month, including major oil refining infrastructure there.</p><p> In a statement, the Fed said the 'unfortunate' developments related to the hurricane 'have increased uncertainty about near-term economic performance, but 'it is the committee's view that they do not pose a more persistent threat.'</p><p> 'Rather, monetary policy accommodation, coupled with robust underlying growth in productivity, is providing ongoing support to economic activity,' it said.</p><p> 'Higher energy and other costs have the potential to add to inflation pressures,' the Fed said. 'However, core inflation has been relatively low in recent months and longer-term inflation expectations remain contained.'</p><p> 'With the underlying inflation expected to be contained, the committee believes that policy accommodation can be removed at a pace that is likely to be measured,' the Fed said.</p><p> The panel perceived that upside and downside risks to the attainment of both sustainable growth and price stability 'should be kept roughly equal' with appropriate monetary policy action, the Fed said.</p><p> The Fed said the hurricane came at a time when output appeared poised to continue growing 'at a good pace.'</p><p> 'The widespread devastation in the Gulf region, the associated dislocation of economic activity, and the boost to energy prices imply that spending, production and employment will be set back in the near term,' it said.</p><p> 'In addition to elevating premiums for some energy products, the disruption to the production and refining infrastructure may add to energy price volatility,' the Fed said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:5543-T5M1-JCF4-K4VF-00000-00Ties with Japan Deepened thru Relief Operations: U.S. Officials2012-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:18:33ZLexisNexisTies with Japan Deepened thru Relief Operations: U.S. OfficialsWashington, March 5

U.S. relief operations in the wake of the catastrophic earthquake and tsunami in Japan last March have further strengthened ties between the two close allies, high-ranking U.S. officials stressed at a ceremony in Washington Monday.

Real allies help each other, U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Thomas Nides said at the ceremony held at the Japanese ambassador's official residence to commemorate victims of the March 11 disaster and wish for reconstruction of afflicted areas. More than 400 U.S. government officials were invited to the event.

Japan lent support to the United States in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001 and massive Hurricane Katrina in 2005, Nides recalled.

Among key guests from the military, Gen. Martin Dempsey, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, noted the bilateral alliance was reinforced by U.S. forces' "Tomodachi" relief operations in the disaster-devastated areas, mainly in northeastern Japan.

He also praised Japan for demonstrating remarkable strength in the past year.

The ceremony was also joined by the sister of Taylor Anderson, the first American victim of the disaster, whose body was found in Ishinomaki, Miyagi Prefecture, where she was teaching English under the Japan Exchange and Teaching Program.

urn:contentItem:54N6-XKV1-DY0W-X4XM-00000-00March 11 disaster inflates insurance claims to record high in 20112012-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:18:33ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSMarch 11 disaster inflates insurance claims to record high in 2011NEW YORK Jan. 5

Natural disasters including the March 11 earthquake and tsunami in Japan made 2011 the costliest year ever both in terms of economic losses and insured losses, a major reinsurance company said Wednesday.

Insurance claims surged 2.5-fold to $105 billion (8 trillion yen), exceeding the previous record of $101 billion set in 2005 when Hurricane Katrina caused extensive damage in the United States, according to Munich Re AG. Of an estimated $380 billion in economic losses, almost two-thirds stemmed from the earthquakes in Japan and New Zealand, the German reinsurer said.

The March earthquake and tsunami in Japan was the most destructive of the around 820 natural disasters last year, resulting in $35 billion to $40 billion in insurance claims. Even excluding the consequences of the subsequent nuclear crisis at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant, the quake and tsunami in northeastern Japan caused $210 billion in economic losses, the company estimated.

The Christchurch earthquake in February was the second costliest natural disaster for insurers with $13 billion in claims, followed by the massive flooding in Thailand with $10 billion. Severe storms and tornadoes in the United States in April led to claims totaling $7.3 billion and Hurricane Irene in August caused $7.0 billion in insured losses.

urn:contentItem:4H2F-4TT0-00JR-G08F-00000-00<published>2005-09-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>95 countries offer total $1 bil. in hurricane relief to U.S.</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>WASHINGTON, Sept. 7</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Ninety-five countries have offered the United States almost $1 billion in relief aid since Hurricane Katrina battered the U.S. Gulf Coast from Florida to Louisiana, the State Department said Wednesday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Japan has contributed about $1 million, around the same amount as Iraq and Bangladesh and lower than South Korea's $30 million, China's $5.01 million and India's $5 million.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> 'Japan's overall aid will come to a substantial amount when the public and private contributions are combined, as the private sector is increasingly offering aid,' a Japanese diplomatic source said, citing Toyota Motor Corp.'s $5 million.</p><p>In response to criticism that the United States is refusing to accept contributions from abroad, Executive Secretary Harry Thomas, appointed to coordinate contributions, said the State Department is working to match the offers with the need on the ground.</p><p> Thomas said the worst thing that could happen is for supplies to be delivered where they are unnecessary and may deteriorate before being used.</p><p> 'The last thing we want to do is take something that can't be utilized, can't be utilized quickly, accurately and to the benefit of the American people,' Thomas said. 'So we have to look at each offer closely and we go back to people and we are doing that.'</p><p> Referring to Kuwait's offer, worth $400 million, to supply crude oil on top of $100 million in cash, Thomas said, 'What the United States needs is gasoline, not crude, so we're trying to figure out...there are many options on the table of how this can be best utilized.'</p><p> Thomas said officials of the department's Bureau of Diplomatic Security have traveled to New Orleans to check the condition of foreign diplomatic missions there.</p><p> 'Two consulates, the Japanese and French consulates, remain under water,' he said.</p><p> On Wednesday, President George W. Bush requested an additional $51.8 billion from Congress, on top of last week's request for $10.5 billion that Congress approved almost immediately.</p><p> 'This will be for ongoing search and rescue operations, food, water, medicine, and action to address public health issues that may arise, among other things,' White House spokesman Scott McClellan said.</p><p> The White House has anticipated that this will not be the end of government funds going to relieve and rebuild the afflicted region.</p><p> 'There will be more that will be needed to cover the longer-term response and rebuilding efforts, and we continue to work on assessing those needs,' McClellan said.</p><p> Hurricane Katrina made landfall in Florida on Aug. 25, moved into the Gulf of Mexico and intensified, then ripped through Louisiana and Mississippi on Aug. 29. Three breaches in the levee system on the Lake Pontchartrain side of New Orleans on Aug. 30 resulted in massive flooding of the entire city, forcing the evacuation of over a million people.</p><p> More than a week after the storm hit, federal, state and local authorities are still attempting to evacuate those who remain in New Orleans. Reports have estimated that removing water alone from the city, most of which is below sea level, may take months.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Japanese businesses, Texans brace for Hurricane Rita's onslaught</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>NEW YORK, Sept. 22</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Japanese businesses based in the Houston area that are in the path of Hurricane Rita, which is likely to make landfall early Saturday, are busy preparing for the storm's onslaught.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Although downgraded to Category 4 as it swept across the Gulf of Mexico on Thursday with winds at 232 kilometers per hour, Rita is still considered dangerous -- packing the same strength as Hurricane Katrina, which devastated the Gulf states late last month.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Rita was classified earlier Thursday as Category 5 with maximum winds of 280 kph.</p><p>Masayuki Sudo, the Houston branch manager for Yamato Transport, U.S.A., said by telephone on Thursday that he plans to wait out the storm in the company's warehouse along with another Japanese manager so that they can secure the premises if looters try to break in after the storm passes.</p><p> Sudo watched television news reports of the widespread looting that took place in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, which killed more than 1,000 people in Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida and Georgia.</p><p> Sudo had already bought enough food and water to last several days and is prepared in the event of electricity outages.</p><p> From his office, which overlooks a highway overpass, he watched as thousands of Houston residents tried to leave the city by car.</p><p> Meanwhile, CNN reported that some 2 million residents were evacuating the city and from other low-lying areas but hundreds of thousands were stuck in massive traffic jams.</p><p> 'It seems that they are only moving about 10 inches an hour and were running out of gas,' Sudo said. 'People are panicked and are stranded on the highways.'</p><p> In the area around the Yamato warehouse he said gas stands are already out of gas and supermarkets are closed.</p><p> Several other Japanese staff members have already left the premises. Two employees left Houston, while two others opted to wait out the storm in their homes and another decided to take refuge at a nearby church.</p><p>NEC Solutions America, a subsidiary of NEC America, which has 30 employees, had ordered its workers to leave the premises and to evacuate with their families.</p><p> The employees have also been instructed to take their portable computers with them and to remain in contact via the Internet. They are also expected to report their whereabouts to the headquarters in California by noon Monday.</p><p> As a precaution, all the desktop computers in the office are being moved away from windows and are being secured in safer locations. Once the workplace computers are stowed away then the office will be closed up by Thursday evening, a company spokesman said.</p><p> According to the Japan Business Association of Houston there are nearly 70 Japanese businesses in the Houston area.</p><p> It is feared that rainfall from the hurricane will hit ravaged New Orleans again in the coming days. Engineers are worried that floodwaters could be sent back into the neighborhoods that have just been dried out over the last week.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:4H5M-J0T0-00JR-G2WR-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">144760</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-31</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="497"/><timeReceived>200509222109</timeReceived><publicationInfo><publicationName>Japan Economic Newswire</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2005 Kyodo News Service</copyright><publicationDate month="09" day="22" year="2005"><dateText>September 22, 2005 Thursday</dateText></publicationDate></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="company"><classificationItem score="57"><className>YAMATO TRANSPORT USA INC </className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="52"><className> NEC CORP OF AMERICA </className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="industry"><classificationItem score="57"><className>NAICS488510 FREIGHT TRANSPORTATION ARRANGEMENT </className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="57"><className> SIC4731 ARRANGEMENT OF TRANSPORTATION OF FREIGHT & CARGO </className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="57"><className> SIC4513 AIR COURIER SERVICES </className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="57"><className> SIC4215 COURIER SERVICES EX. urn:contentItem:4HW4-4JV0-00JR-G3YR-00000-00<published>2005-12-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Terrorism in numerous cities tops 2005's biggest int'l news</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, Dec. 23</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Terrorist attacks on the London underground system and subsequent attacks in Egypt, Indonesia, India and Jordan were ranked as the top international news story of 2005, according to a Kyodo News poll released Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The poll covered senior editors at Kyodo News, its member newspapers and other subscriber organizations who were asked to choose what they considered the major international events this year.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Following are the 10 top international news stories of 2005:</p><p nitf:lede="true"> (1) Large scale terrorist attacks occur around the world</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Four explosions occurred on London's underground rail network and a bus, killing more than 50 people on July 7, the second day of a Group of Eight summit at Gleneagles. In simultaneous bombings at the Egyptian Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheik in the month, more than 80 people were killed.</p><p>About 20 people were killed in October in bombings in Bali Island, Indonesia, and more than 60 were killed in New Delhi, India. Terrorist attacks at three luxurious hotels in Jordan in November also killed more than 50 people. In all cases, Islamic radicals are believed to have committed the attacks.</p><p> (2) Iraq's new Constitution, election</p><p>Iraq held its first democratic election in January and an interim government was established in April. A bill for a new Constitution was approved by a national referendum in October and an election to choose an administration under the new Constitution was held Dec. 15.</p><p> Terrorist attacks continued and more than 120 people were killed Feb. 28 in central Iraq, followed by attacks in Baghdad on Sept. 14 which killed more than 150. A Japanese man working for a British security company was killed in May in an attack by a militant group.</p><p> The number of casualties in the U.S. force has surpassed 2,100, and an estimated 30,000 on the Iraqi side since the March 2003 start of the Iraq war.</p><p> (3) Earthquake in northeastern Pakistan</p><p> On Oct. 8, an earthquake with a magnitude of 7.6 hit Kashmir, which is under territorial dispute between Pakistan and India, killing over 70,000 people and leaving 3 million people affected.</p><p> (4) Crude oil price exceeds $70 per barrel</p><p> The price of crude oil futures exceeded $70 per barrel after oil refinery facilities in the southern United States were disabled by a hurricane. After the International Energy Agency released emergency oil reserves, the price came down to the $50 level, but with a cold wave hitting the northeastern United States, the price surged again above $60 per barrel in December.</p><p> (5) Hurricane Katrina hits southern U.S.</p><p> Hurricane Katrina made landfall in the southern United States in late August, killing approximately 1,300 people in Louisiana and Mississippi, and more than 6,000 people were reported still missing as of late November. Much of the city of New Orleans was submerged and the population dropped sharply afterward.</p><p> (6) Concern for new flu rises as bird flu spreads</p><p> Concerns over a new strain of influenza rose as the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian flu virus that had previously been detected only in Asia spread to Russia, Romania and other European countries. Many people fell victim to bird flu in such countries as China, Thailand and Indonesia.</p><p> (7) Multinational treaty on N. Korean nuclear disarmament</p><p>North Korea officially announced Feb. 10 that it has nuclear weapons and would suspend involvement in talks. In September's six-way talks, however, North Korea agreed to abandon all its nuclear programs, rejoin an international nuclear treaty and allow nuclear inspections in exchange for energy aid and security affirmations.</p><p> (8) Anti-Japan rallies in China</p><p> Rallies and riots took place in major Chinese cities in April in opposition to Japan's aim to become a permanent member of the United Nations' Security Council. Japanese companies and diplomatic facilities were targeted and their buildings were damaged by mobs.</p><p> An anti-Japan demonstration also turned into a riot on April 16, forcing the Public Security Bureau to issue a statement saying unauthorized demonstrations are illegal.</p><p> (9) Bush wins 2nd term, support drops</p><p>U.S. President George W. Bush began his second administration on Jan. 20 after he was reelected in the presidential election. In his State of the Union Address in February, he said the United States will work with its allies to help achieve freedom in the Middle East and other parts of the globe with the goal of ending 'tyranny.'</p><p> But as the war in Iraq drags on and with Bush failing to take quick responsive measures to Hurricane Katrina, criticism mounted of the administration. In October, an aide to the vice president was indicted over leaking the name of a Central Intelligence Agency agent, and November polls showed support for Bush had fallen to the upper half of the 30 percent level.</p><p> (10) China revalues yuan</p><p> China revalued the yuan on July 21 by about 2 percent, while putting an end to the currency's decade-old peg to the U.S. dollar. The United States, which had a large trade deficit with China, is demanding China to revalue the yuan again, claiming the percentage is not enough.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4HC8-1M70-00JR-G3VF-00000-00<published>2005-10-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Fed reports continued economic growth in Sept. despite hurricane</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>WASHINGTON, Oct. 19</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The U.S. economy continued to expand overall in September despite 'significant' negative effects on the districts hit by Hurricane Katrina in late August, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday in a periodic business sentiment survey.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The October Beige Book report also pointed to rising energy and other prices, thus increasing expectations for the Fed to carry out its 12th consecutive rate hike to tame inflation at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting Nov. 1.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The report serves as one of the key materials for FOMC meetings.</p><p>'Economic activity continued to expand in September,' the U.S. central bank said in the report, compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia based on information collected by the 12 Fed districts before Oct. 11.</p><p> 'Most districts described the pace of activity as moderate or gradual,' it said. But the Atlanta district, which encompasses the hurricane-devastated area, reported 'mixed economic conditions, with significant negative efforts...from hurricane damage.'</p><p> The Dallas district also reported that it 'experienced noticeable disruptions' due to the hurricanes Katrina and Rita although its economy expanded overall.</p><p> As for inflation, the Fed said, 'All districts reported cost increases for energy, petroleum-based products, building materials and shipping.'</p><p> 'Several districts indicated that input costs increases are being passed through to retail prices,' it said.</p><p> With employment rising and some districts reporting 'some tightening in labor markets,' the Fed said, 'Wage increases have been moderate although a number of districts noted increased upward pressure on wages and salaries in the service sectors and for some skilled companies in several industries.'</p><p> 'Retail sales of general merchandise increased in most districts, but a number of banks reported that retail sales were either below par or weak,' the Fed said, noting that auto sales 'fell throughout the districts.'</p><p> 'Manufacturing advanced in all districts except St. Louis and Atlanta,' it said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:535D-G071-DY0W-X1HJ-00000-00IEA members to release oil reserves to control rising oil prices2011-06-23T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:18:33ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSIEA members to release oil reserves to control rising oil pricesPARIS June 23

Member countries of the International Energy Agency decided at its board meeting Thursday to release 60 million barrels of oil from their emergency oil reserves in the coming month to stem rising oil prices, IEA chief Nobuo Tanaka said.

The release, representing 2 million barrels of oil per day, is aimed at offsetting the ongoing disruption to oil supplies from Libya and preventing high oil prices from undermining the global economy, Tanaka, the agency's executive director, told a news conference in Paris.

Tanaka added that an expected increase in demand for oil in Japan for use in reconstruction following the massive March 11 earthquake and tsunami was also a factor behind the decision.

It is the third time that the IEA has decided to release stocks to cover lost supplies, following similar decisions in 1991 amid the turmoil following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and in 2005 when Hurricane Katrina damaged U.S. refineries in the Gulf of Mexico.

IEA member countries have been preparing for the release since the failure earlier this month of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree on an increase in oil production.

The 28 IEA member countries are obliged to hold emergency oil reserves equivalent to at least 90 days of net oil imports. Total oil stocks in IEA member countries amount to over 4.1 billion barrels.

urn:contentItem:4H0J-MSB0-002V-119M-00000-00<published>2005-08-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:33Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Tokyo Stocks Rebound in Morning after U.S. Gains</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>Tokyo, Aug. 30</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Stocks sprang back on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday morning as investors drew comfort from Wall Street's overnight rebound.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Players simply moved to buy back shares since U.S. stocks did not suffer a setback overnight contrary to our expectations the day before," said Toshihiko Matsuno, deputy equity general manager at SMBC Friend Securities Co.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Helped by the wave of buybacks, the 225-issue Nikkei average rose 96.63 points to end the morning at 12,406.46. The Nikkei, which fell 129.65 points Monday, briefly jumped to 12,438.80 with a gain of more than 120 points.</p><p>The TOPIX index of all first-section issues was up 9.00 points at 1,267.64 at the morning close. The index lost 13.82 points the previous day.</p><p>The morning's rebound also came after crude oil prices eased somewhat in New York trading overnight as the damage from massive Hurricane Katrina was not as severe as had been feared, the same factor that propped up U.S. equities on Monday, brokers said.</p><p>But after the initial round of buying ran its course, major stock indexes failed to extend their gains due to the absence of further incentives, brokers said. <br/>Tokyo Stocks Rebound in Morning after U.S. Gains</p><p>Gainers easily beat losers 971 to 469 on the TSE's first section in the morning, while 198 issues were unchanged.</p><p>Half-day volume came to 860 million shares.</p><p>Although worries about soaring crude oil prices subsided somewhat, market players hesitated to step up buying in the morning due to the lack of conviction about U.S. stocks' sustained strength and about whether foreign investors will remain heavy buyers of Japanese stocks, brokers said.</p><p>"The worst-case scenario on Hurricane Katrina did not come true. But many players are still taking to the sidelines," said Teruhisa Ishikawa, equity manager at Mizuho Investors Securities Co.</p><p>Ishikawa said that the Nikkei is likely to consolidate its downside for the time being, while players keep close tabs on Japan's industrial production data for July, due out Wednesday, and a coming spate of U.S. economic data, including Friday's jobs report for August.</p><p>But SMBC Friend's Matsuno said that historical evidence suggests that stocks may head higher toward the Sept. 11 general election in Japan as politicians attempt to paint a rosy picture for the economy during election campaigns. <br/>Tokyo Stocks Rebound in Morning after U.S. Gains</p><p>Technology issues such as Sony, Matsushita Electric and Fanuc bounced back.</p><p>Banking groups Mizuho, Sumitomo Mitsui, UFJ and Mitsubishi Tokyo posted strong gains although Sumitomo Trust lost ground after it on Monday announced secondary offering plans for its shares.</p><p>Also upbeat were steelmakers including Nippon Steel and shipping firms like Mitsui O.S.K. Lines.</p><p>Isuzu spurted to a new year-to-date high in active trading. Other automakers were also higher, including Toyota, Nissan, and Daihatsu, which has announced a plan to release the first gasoline-electric hybrid commercial minivehicle.</p><p>Eisai attracted buying interest after the drug maker on Monday announced successful results of its Phase II clinical trial in North America of a new drug for treating severe sepsis.</p><p>By contrast, oil companies, including Inpex and Cosmo Oil, fell back. <br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5326-X781-JBHV-61B9-00000-00Japan quake orphans visit Ground Zero in New York2011-06-08T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:18:33ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSJapan quake orphans visit Ground Zero in New YorkNEW YORK June 8

A group of Japanese students from Miyagi Prefecture who lost their parents in the March 11 quake and tsunami disaster on Wednesday visited New York's Ground Zero, the site of the 2001 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center.

The visit was part of an exchange with young American people who lost their parents or other loved ones to the terror attacks or hurricane Katrina, as well as joint street fundraising activity.

The group, which also includes family members of the 1995 Great Hanshin Earthquake victims, arrived in New York on Tuesday for a five-day visit, during which they will also talk at high schools about the experience of surviving disasters.

The visit was organized by the Tokyo-based nonprofit organization Ashinaga. Ashinaga, named for the American novel "Daddy-Long-Legs," provides financial assistance to orphans and children of single-parent households.

Among the participants is Shoya Kasai, 16, a student of Ishinomaki high school in Miyagi Prefecture who lost one of his parents in the March disaster.

The group plans to raise funds on the streets of the city, together with the American youths, to help Ashinaga build a mental care facility for orphaned children in the quake-hit city of Sendai in the prefecture.

On Tuesday, Kasai and others have met Hilary Strauch, a 21-year-old junior at New York's Vassar College who lost her father in the Sept. 11 attacks.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Japanese oil distributors to export gasoline to U.S.</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, Sept. 14</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Japan's four biggest oil distributors said Wednesday they will export gasoline to the United States as part of efforts to alleviate global supply concerns in the wake of Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Nippon Oil Corp., Idemitsu Kosan Co., Cosmo Oil Co. and Japan Energy Corp. will release a total of 25,000 kiloliters of gasoline from their reserves in line with the Japanese government's decision last week to free part of petroleum products held by private firms as mandatory stockpiles.</p><p>They will export from a refinery facility in Sendai as early as this weekend, and the gasoline is expected to arrive in the United States early next month.</p><p> The government's decision came in a concerted action by the International Energy Agency to help stabilize the oil market in the wake of the hurricane, which sparked worldwide supply concerns by forcing oil production and refinery facilities along the Gulf of Mexico to suspend operations earlier this month.</p><p>Cosmo Oil will also export 110,000 kl of diesel oil to Australia.</p><p>Exxon Mobil Corp. and Showa Shell Sekiyu K.K., a Royal Dutch/Shell Group company, have separately decided to export petroleum products from Japan to the United States and Europe.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Showa Shell to export gasoline to U.S. to ease supply concerns</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>TOKYO, Sept. 13</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Showa Shell Sekiyu K.K. said Tuesday it will export gasoline from Japan to the United States in mid-September to help ease supply concerns in the wake of Hurricane Katrina.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Japan's major oil distributor, affiliated with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said it will export 24,000 kiloliters of gasoline to the United States as part of its contribution to the Japanese government's decision last week to release private oil reserves.</p><p>The decision followed the International Energy Agency's call for concerted action to help stabilize the global oil market.</p><p> A Showa Shell Sekiyu official said the company is considering providing additional petroleum products if necessary.</p><p> Among major oil distributors, Exxon Mobil Corp. said last Thursday it will export petroleum products from Japan to the United States and Europe.</p><p> Other leading oil distributors in Japan including Idemitsu Kosan Co. are considering following suit.</p><p> The Showa Shell Sekiyu official said the Japanese oil industry is determined to make efforts to allay supply concerns.</p><p> Several Japanese oil companies are discussing a plan to arrange a tanker together to ship their petroleum products to the United States, the official added.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">JEN2005</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4H3P-V7G0-00JR-G17M-00000-00<published>2005-09-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-08-20T19:18:32Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>INTERNATIONAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Bush, Koizumi agree to beef up alliance</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>WASHINGTON, Sept. 13</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">U.S. President George W. Bush and Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi agreed Tuesday to strengthen the alliance between the two countries in their first talks since Sunday's general election in Japan, White House spokesman Scott McClellan said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Bush called Koizumi to congratulate him on his victory in the House of Representatives election and praised him for his 'strong leadership both domestically and in the war on terror,' McClellan said.</p><p>The two leaders 'discussed how we could continue working together to further strengthen our alliance and advance global peace and security,' McClellan said.</p><p> Earlier in Tokyo, Japanese Foreign Ministry officials said Koizumi expressed Japan's readiness to do its utmost to support those who have been hit by Hurricane Katrina, saying he expects authorities of the two countries to coordinate closely to that end.</p><p> McClellan said Koizumi also extended his condolences to the American people in the aftermath of the hurricane.</p><p> Koizumi's dominant Liberal Democratic Party won 296 of the 480 seats of the House of Representatives in the election. Before the election, the LDP had 249 lower house seats. A party needs 241 seats for a majority.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Singapore sends 3 helicopters to help hurricane-hit U.S. state</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>SINGAPORE, Sept. 2</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Singapore has deployed three military helicopters and a team of 38 soldiers to help the United States in relief operations in the wake of Hurricane Katrina, the Defense Ministry said Friday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The three Chinook helicopters belonging to the Singapore Air Force were dispatched Thursday, it said in a statement.</p><p>The helicopters will be working closely with the Texas Army National Guard and undertake resupply and airlift missions.</p><p> The military personnel are aircrew and technicians.</p><p> The helicopters were flown to Louisiana from Grand Prairie, Texas, where they have been based for sometime as part of a training detachment.</p><p>Singapore is one of the United States' closest allies in Southeast Asia.</p><p> The United States has sold state-of-the-art fighter jets and other sophisticated weapons to Singapore, and these are based in the United States for several years for training due to the small island-state's lack of airspace.</p><p> Leaders from the two countries recently signed a strategic framework agreement for closer partnership in defense and security to step up their defense cooperation. In 1990, the two countries signed a memorandum of understanding on military cooperation that gave American forces use of facilities in Singapore.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4NW5-PJM0-TWB6-G2KT-00000-00Top Bush aide Bartlett leaving White House: AP2007-06-01T00:00:00Z2025-08-20T19:18:33ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSTop Bush aide Bartlett leaving White House: APWASHINGTON June 1

Dan Bartlett, one of U.S. President George W. Bush's most trusted advisers and his longest-serving aide, said Friday he is resigning to begin a career outside of government, the Associated Press reported.

Bartlett has been with Bush for nearly 14 years, from Bush's first campaign as governor of Texas, through two races for the White House and more than six years of a presidency marked by costly wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and an ongoing battle against terrorism.

As counselor to the president, Bartlett has been at the center of White House decision-making, stepping into the public eye in times of trouble to defend Bush on everything from the unpopular war in Iraq to the government's bungled response to Hurricane Katrina and the Republicans' loss of Congress.

"He can talk to the president in a candid way, in sort of a family way, that almost nobody else can," White House chief of staff Joshua Bolten told AP.

With the exception of Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld's resignation last November, Bartlett's departure marks the first major turnover in Bush's senior staff since a major reshuffling a year ago to reinvigorate the administration and overcome low poll ratings.

Bartlett's resignation is effective around July 4, Bolten was quoted as saying.
